explanations: The translator added 'of the Day' after 'Dawning' (French: l'Aurore) to provide further specification and clarity for the English reader, aligning with common phrasing.

This phrase provides a scientific explanation (oblique/faint beams, lack of strength to penetrate) for how the air intercepts sunlight, which is an elaboration not present in the French text that simply states the air is 'fort grossier' (very coarse) and stops some rays. This addition aims to clarify the physical process for the reader.

The translator added this phrase to interpret and emphasize that the light of dawn and twilight is an additional, almost accidental benefit from Nature, elaborating on the French 'par dessus ce qui nous est dû' (over and above what is due to us).

The translator added the adjective 'faint' to describe the 'Beams of the Sun,' a detail not in the French 'les rayons qu'il reçoit du Soleil' (the rays it receives from the Sun), potentially for vividness or consistency with earlier explanations about weak light.

The addition of 'I suppose,' softens the philosopher's statement, making it sound more like a personal conjecture rather than the direct assertion implied by the French 'Vous n'avez donc...' (You therefore do not have...).

The translator replaced the French pronoun 'Vous' (you, plural) with the explicit noun phrase 'the Inhabitants of the Moon' to provide clarity and avoid ambiguity for the English reader regarding whom the philosopher is addressing.
The translator added 'or Dawning' as an explanatory appositive to 'Aurora,' clarifying the term for an English audience possibly less familiar with 'Aurora' as a standalone term for dawn.
The translator added 'at Noon' to 'the glorious Appearance of the Sun,' specifying the time of its peak intensity. The French 'l'arrivée du Soleil' (the arrival of the Sun) is less specific.
Similar to a previous instance, 'So that the Inhabitants of the Moon' is added to explicitly identify the subject, clarifying the French 'Vous estes...' (You are...) for the English reader.

This phrase significantly elaborates on the French 'vous voila tombés dans des tenebres profondes' (there you are fallen into profound darkness). The English adds dramatic detail about the speed ('as quick as the former'), the mechanism ('down falls the Curtain'), and the immediacy ('instantly they are reduc'd'), enhancing the imagery of sudden transition to darkness.

The translator added 'or Interstices' as a synonym or further explanation for 'Mediums' (which translates the French 'milieu'), potentially to offer a more specific or learned term to the English reader for the transitional state between day and night.

This clause is added to explicitly contrast the Moon's lack of gradual transitions between day and night with Earth's experience ('which we enjoy'), providing context and relatability for the target audience. The French original focuses solely on the Moon.

The translator elaborated on the French 'les nuages d'où tombent les pluyes' (clouds from which rain falls) by adding the descriptive phrase 'condens'd into black Clouds,' making the imagery more vivid and specific.

The addition of 'upon us' to the description of rain falling from clouds ('which pour down Rain upon us') personalizes the phenomenon for the reader, which is not explicit in the French 'd'où tombent les pluyes' (from which rain falls).

This phrase adds a detailed scientific explanation of how rainbows are formed (through reflections and refractions of sunbeams on clouds), a mechanism not described in the simpler French statement 'l'Arc-en-ciel se forme dans les nuages d'où tombent les pluyes.'

The addition of 'in Nature' to the phrase 'the ugliest and most dis- agreeable Causes in Nature' generalizes the philosophical point being made, extending it beyond the immediate context to a broader statement about natural phenomena.

The translator rephrased the French 'Puis qu'il n'y a autour de la Lune ny vapeurs assez grossieres, ny nuages pluvieux' (Since there are around the Moon neither coarse enough vapours, nor rainy clouds) to introduce 'the Purity of the Air of the Moon' as an active agent that 'deprives it of Clouds, Vapours and Rain.' This causal framing and the explicit mention of 'Rain' (implied in 'nuages pluvieux' but stated directly here) are additions for clarity and explanatory force.

The translator specified 'the Lovers in the Moon compare their Mistresses,' making the reference more concrete and aligning with common poetic comparisons. The French 'les Belles de ce Pays-là?' (the Beauties of that Country?) is more general, though it could allude to subjects of comparison.

This phrase is added for emphasis and clarity, explicitly stating what is missing for making comparisons (the rainbow and aurora), which is implied by the French rhetorical question 'Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!' (What a lost source of comparisons!).

chunks.source_manual: <P048>Je n'aurois pas grand regret à ces comparaisons là, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, & je trouve qu'on est assez bien recompensé dans la Lune <UP></UP>, de n'avoir ny Aurore ny Arc-en- ciel, car on ne doit avoir par la mesme raison ny Foudres ny Tonnerres, puisque ce sont aussi des choses qui se forment dans les nüages. On a de beaux jours toûjours serains pendant lesquels on ne perd point le Soleil de veuë <NCE></NCE>. On n'a point de nuits où toutes les Etoiles ne se montrent <UP></UP>; on ne connoist ny les orages ny les tempestes, ny tout ce qui paroist estre un effet de la colere du Ciel, trouvez-vous qu'on soit tant à plaindre? Vous me faites voir la Lune comme un séjour enchanté, répondis-je; cependant je ne sçay s'il est si délicieux d'avoir toûjours sur la teste, un Soleil ardent dont aucun nüage ne modere la chaleur. Peut-estre aussi est-ce à cause de cela que la Nature a creusé dans la Lune des especes de Puits, qui sont assez grands pour estre apperceus par nos Lunettes; car ce ne sont point des Vallées qui soient entre des Montagnes, ce sont des creux que l'on voit au milieu de certains lieux plats. Que sçait-on si les Habitans de la Lune, incommodez par l'ardeur perpetuelle du Soleil, ne se refugient point dans ces grands Puits? Ils n'habitent peut-estre point ailleurs, c'est-là qu'ils bâtissent leurs Villes. Nous voyons icy que la Rome soûterraine estoit presque aussi grande que la Rome qui estoit sur Terre. Il ne faudroit qu'oster celle-cy, le reste seroit une Ville à la maniere de la Lune. Tout un Peuple est dans un Puits, & d'un Puits à l'autre il y a des chemins soûterrains pour la communication des Peuples. Vous vous mocquez de cette vision, j'y consens de tout mon cœr; cependant, à vous parler tres serieusement, vous pourriez vous tromper plûtost que moy. Vous croyez que les Gens de la Lune doivent habiter sur la surface de leur Planete, parce que nous habitons sur la surface de la nostre: c'est tout le contraire, puisque nous habitons sur la surface de nostre Planete, ils pourroient bien n'habiter pas sur la surface de la leur. D'icy là il faut que toutes choses soient bien differentes. <UP></UP></P048> <P049>Il n'importe, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je ne puis me resoudre à laisser vivre les Habitans de la Lune dans une obscurité perpetuelle. Vous y auriez encore plus de peine, répris-je, si vous sçaviez qu'un grand Philosophe de l'Antiquité a fait de la Lune le séjour des Ames qui ont merité icy d'estre bien-heureuses. Toute leur felicité consiste en ce qu'elles y entendent l'Harmonie que les Corps Celestes font par leurs mouvemens; mais comme il pretend que quand la Lune tombe dans l'ombre de la Terre, elles ne peuvent plus entendre cette Harmonie <UP></UP>; alors, dit-il, ces Ames crient comme des desesperées, & la Lune se haste le plus qu'elle peut de les tirer d'un endroit si facheux. Nous devrions donc, repliqua-t-elle, voir arriver icy les Bienheureux de la Lune, car apparemment on nous les envoye aussi, & dans ces deux Planetes on croit avoir assez pourveu à la felicité des Ames, de les avoir transportées dans un autre Monde. Serieusement, répris-je, ce ne seroit pas un plaisir mediocre de voir plusieurs Mondes differens. Ce Voyage me réjoüit quelquefois beaucoup à ne le faire qu'en imagination, & que seroit-ce, si on le faisoit en effet? Cela vaudroit bien mieux que d'aller d'icy au Japon, c'est à dire de ramper avec beaucoup de peine d'un point de la Terre sur un autre, pour ne voir que des hommes. Eh bien, dit-elle, faisons le Voyage des Planetes, comme nous pourrons; qui nous en empesche? Allons nous placer dans tous ces differens points de veuê, & de là considerons l'Univers. N'avons-nous plus rien à voir dans la Lune? Je croy que non, répondis-je, du moins je vous y ay fait voir tout ce qui estoit de ma connoissance. Au sortir de la Lune en tirant vers le Soleil, on trouve Venus. Sur Vénus je reprens le <NCE>Saint Denis</NCE>. Venus tourne sur elle-mesme, & autour du Soleil <UP>comme la Lune</UP>, on découvre avec les <NCP><IIM>Lunettes d'approche</IIM></NCP>, que Venus aussi-bien que la Lune, est tantost en Croissant, tantost en Décours, tantost pleine selon les diverses situations où elle est à l'égard de la Terre. La Lune selon toutes les apparences est habitée, pourquoy Vénus ne le sera-t-elle pas aussi? Mais, interrompit-elle, en disant toûjours Pourquoy non, vous m'allez mettre des Habitans dans toutes les Planetes? N'en doutez pas, répliquay-je, ce Pourquoy a une vertu qui suffira pour peupler tout. Nous voyons que toutes les Planetes sont de la mesme nature, toutes des Corps <IIM>opaques</IIM> qui ne reçoivent de la lumiere que du Soleil, qui se la renvoyent les uns aux autres, & qui n'ont que les mesmes mouvemens, jusque là tout est égal. Cependant il faudroit concevoir que ces grands Corps auroient esté faits pour n'estre point habitez, que ce seroit là leur condition naturelle, & qu'il y auroit une exception justement en faveur de la Terre toute seule. Qui voudra le croire, le croye; pour moy, je ne m'y puis pas resoudre? Je vous trouve, dit-elle, bien affermy dans vôtre opinion depuis quelques instans. <UP></UP> Je viens de voir le moment que la Lune seroit deserte, & que vous ne vous en souciïez pas beaucoup, & presentement si on osoit vous dire que toutes les Planetes ne sont pas aussi habitées que la Terre, je voy bien que vous vous mettriez en colere. Il est vray, répondis-je, que dans le moment où vous venez de me surprendre, si vous m'eussiez contredit sur les Habitans des Planetes, non seulement je vous les aurois soutenus, mais je crois que je vous aurois dit comment ils estoient tous faits. Il y a des momens pour croire, & je ne les ay jamais si bien crûs que dans celuy là; mais presentement que je suis un peu plus de sens froid, je ne laisse pas de trouver qu'il seroit bien étrange que la Terre fust aussi habitée qu'elle l'est, & que les autres Planetes ne le fussent point du tout; car ne croyez pas que nous voyions tout ce qui habite la Terre; il y a autant d'especes d'Animaux invisibles que de visibles. Nous voyons depuis l'Elephant jusqu'au <UP></UP> Ciron; là finit nostre veuë; mais au Ciron commence une multitude infinie d'Animaux, dont il est l'Elephant, & que la simple veuë ne sçauroit appercevoir. On a vu avec des <RW>Lunettes</RW> beaucoup de Liqueurs toutes remplis de petits Animaux que l'on n'auroit jamais soupçonnez d'y estre, & il y a quelque apparence que le goût qu'elles font sentir, sont les piqueures que ces petits Animaux font à la langue & au palais. Meslez de certaines choses dans quelques-unes de ces Liqueurs, ou exposez-les au Soleil, ou laissez-les se corrompre, voilà aussi-tost de nouvelles especes de petits Animaux.</P049> <P050>Beaucoup de Corps qui paroissent solides <UP></UP>, ne sont que des amas de ces Animaux imperceptibles, qui y trouvent pour leurs mouvemens autant de liberté qu'il leur en faut. Une feüille d'Arbre est un petit Monde habité par des Vermisseaux invisibles, à qui elle paroist d'une étenduë immense, qui y connoissent des Montagnes & des Abismes, & qui d'un costé de la feüille à l'autre n'ont pas plus de communication avec les autres Vermisseaux qui y vivent, que nous avec nos Antipodes. A plus forte raison, ce me semble, une <RW>grosse</RW> Planete sera-t-elle un Monde habité. On a trouvé jusque dans des especes de pierres tres-dures de petits Vers sans nombre, qui y étoient logez de toutes parts dans des vuides insensibles, & qui ne se nourrissoient que de la substance de ces pierres qu'ils rongeoient. Figurez-vous combien il y avoit de ces petits Vers, & pendant combien d'années ils subsistoient de la grosseur d'un grain de sable; & sur cet exemple, quand la Lune ne seroit qu'un amas de rochers, je la ferois plûtost ronger par ses Habitans que de n'y en pas mettre. Enfin tout est vivant, tout est animé <UP></UP>: mettez toutes ces especes d'Animaux nouvellement découvertes, & mesme toutes celles que l'on conçoit aisément qui sont encore à découvrir, avec celles que l'on a toûjours veuës, vous trouverez assurément que la Terre est bien peuplée, & que la Nature y a si liberalement répandu les Animaux, qu'elle ne s'est pas mise en peine que l'on en vist seulement la moitié. Croirez-vous qu'aprés qu'elle a poussé icy sa fecondité jusqu'à l'excés, elle a esté pour toutes les autres Planetes d'une sterilité à n'y rien produire de vivant?</P050>
chunks.target_manual: <P036>I do much regret that loss, said the Marquiese, for in my Opinion, the Inhabitants of the Moon are fully recompens'd for the want of the Rain-bow, day- break and twi-light, since for the same Reason, they have neither Thunder nor Lightning, both which are produc'd by Clouds and Exhalations; they enjoy bright serene Days, and never lose the Sun by Day, <UP>nor the Stars by Night</UP>. They know nothing of Storms and Tempest; which seem to us the effects of the wrath of Heaven. And can you think their condition is so much to be lamented? You, said I, Madam, represent the Moon as a most charming abode. Now methinks it should not be so desirous and agreeable to have a burning Sun always over ones Head, without the interposition of any Clouds to moderate its heat: And it may be for this Reason, Nature has sunk these Caverns in the Moon, which are big enough to be seen by our Telescopes: Who knows but the Inhabitants of the Moon, retire into these Cavities, when they are incommoded with the Excessive heat of the Sun, and it may be they live no where else, but build their Towns and Villages in these hollow places? And do not we know that Rome, which is built under ground, is almost as great as the City above ground? So that if we shou'd suppose, that the City of Rome above ground shou'd be ras'd, and quite remov'd, Rome under ground wou'd then be just such a Town, as those I have imagin'd to be in the Moon. Whole Nations live in these vast Caverns; and I doubt not but there may be Passages under ground, for the communication and commerce of one People and Nation with another. You are pleas'd to laugh, Madam, at my Fancy, do so with all my Heart, I agree you shou'd; and yet you may be more mistaken than I: For you believe, that the Inhabitants of the Moon dwell upon the Surface of their Globe, as we do on that of the Earth; it is very likely that 'tis just the contrary; for there is most certain, a vast difference between their way of living and ours. No matter, said the Marquiese, I cannot resolve to suffer the Inhabitants of the Moon to live in perpetual Darkness. You wou'd be harder put to it, Madam, said I, if you knew that a great Philosopher of old, believ'd the Moon to be the abode and dwelling of the Souls who had merited Happiness by their good Life in this World; and that theit Felicity consisted in hearing the Harmony of the Spheres as they turn'd round, and that they were depriv'd of this heavenly Musick, as often as the Moon was obscur'd by the Shadow of the Earth; and that then these Souls roar'd and cry'd out as in despair, and that the Moon made haste to recover her Light again, to bring the Souls out of that Affliction. At that rate, said she, we shou'd see the bless'd Souls come from the Moon to us; for why shou'd not the Earth be to the Moon, as the Moon is to the Earth, since according to the opinion of your Philosopher, there was no other Felicity for the Souls of the blessed, than to be transported from one World to the other? Seriously, said I, Madam, 'twould be a great Pleasure and Satisfaction to see several different Worlds; and I am often glad, to make these Journeys in Imagination; what joy then it wou'd be to do it in reality; that wou'd be far better than to travel from hence to Iapan, crawling as it were with difficulty from one point of this Globe to another, and still to see nothing but Men and Women over and over again. Well, said she, what hinders, but we shou'd make a Journey through the Planets as well as we can? Let us by imagination place our selves in several Positions, and situations, fit for considering the Universe. Have we no more to see in the Moon? No, said I, at least, I have shown you all I know. Going out of the Moon towards the Sun, the first Planet you meet with is Venus; and here I must again make use of my former Simile of Paris and St. Denis. Venus turns round the Sun on her own Axis, <UP>as the Moon does round the Earth</UP>; and by the means of Telescopes, we discover that Venus waxes and wanes, being sometimes altogether enlightned, and sometimes darkened according to her different Positions in respect to the Earth.</P036> <P037>By all appearance the Moon is inhabited, why shou'd not Venus be so, as well as she? Ay, but interrupted the Marquiese by your why nots, you will people all the Planets. Do not doubt of it, Madam, answer'd I; why has not Nature sufficient to give Inhabitants to 'em all? We see that all the Planets are of the same Nature, that they are all Opaque solid Bodies, having no Light but what they receive from the Sun; which they send one to another by Reflection, and that they have all the same kind of motion; thus far equal, and after all this must we conceive that all these vast Bodies were made not to be inhabited? And that Nature has made only an exception in Favor of the Earth, he that will believe this, may, but for my part I cannot. I find you, said the Marquiese, very resolute and settled in your opinion of a sudden: A little while ago, you wou'd scarce allow the Moon to be inhabited; and seem'd to be very indifferent, whether it were so or not; whereas now, I am confident, you wou'd be very angry with any body that shou'd tell you that all the Planets were not inhabited. It is true, Madam, in the minute wherein you have surpriz'd me, had you contradicted me, as to the Inhabitants of all the Planets, I wou'd not only have defended my opinion, but have proceeded, to have given you an exact description of all the several Inhabitants of the Planets. There are certain Moments of believing things; and I never so firmly believ'd the Planets to be inhabited, as in that Moment I spoke of 'em; but now, after cooler Thoughts, I shou'd think it very strange, that the Earth shou'd be inhabited as it is; and the other Planets shou'd be so entirely desolate and desarted: For you must not think, that we see all the living Creatures that inhabit the Earth. For there are as many several species and kinds of Animals invisible, as there are visible. We see distinctly from the Elephant to the Mite; there our sight is bounded, and there are infinite numbers of living Creatures lesser than a Mite, to whom, a Mite is as big in proportion, as an Elephant is to it. <RW>The late invention of Glasses</RW> call'd Microscopes, have discover'd thousands of small living Creatures, in certain Liquors, which we cou'd never have imagin'd to have been there. And it may be the different tastes of these Liquors, proceed from these little Animals, who bite, and sting our Tongues and Palates. If you mix certain ingredients in these Liquors, <RW>(as Pepper in Water,)</RW> and expose 'em to the heat of the Sun, or let 'em putrefie, you shall see other new species or living Creatures. Several Bodies, which appear to be solid, are nothing else but Collections or little heaps of these imperceptible Animals; who find there as much room, as is requisite for them to move in. The leaf of a Tree, is a little World inhabited, by such invisible little Worms: To them this leaf seems of a vast Extent, they find Hills and Valleys upon it: And there is no more Communication between the living Creatures on the one side, and those on the other, than between us and the Antipodes. And I think there is more reason, to believe a Planet <RW>(which is so vast a Body)</RW> to be inhabited. There has been found in several sorts of very hard Stones, <UP>infinite multitudes</UP> of little Worms, lodg'd all over them in insensible varieties; and who are nourish'd upon the Substance of these Stones which they eat. Consider the vast Numbers of these little Animals, and how long a tract of Years they have liv'd upon a grain of Sand. And by this Argument, tho my Moon were nothing but a confus'd heap of Marble Rocks, I wou'd rather make it be devour'd and consum'd by its Inhabitants, than to place none at all in it.</P037>

chunks.source_manual: <P051>Ma raison est assez bien convaincuë, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, mais mon imagination est accablée de la multitude infinie des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & embarrassée de la diversité qu'il faut établir entre eux; car je voy bien que la Nature, selon qu'elle est ennemie des repetitions, les aura tous faits différens, mais comment se representer cela? Ce n'est pas à l'imagination à prétendre le représenter, répondis-je, elle n'est pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux. On peut seulement apercevoir d'une certaine veuë universelle, la diversité que la Nature doit avoir mise entre tous ces Mondes. Tous les visages sont en general sur un mesme modele; mais ceux de deux grandes Nations, comme des Européens, si vous voulez, & des Africains, paroissent estre faits sur deux modeles particuliers, & il faudroit encore trouver le modele des visages de chaque Famille. Quel secret doit avoir eu la Nature pour varier en tant de manieres une chose aussi simple qu'un visage? Nous ne sommes dans l'Univers que comme une petite Famille, dont tous les visages se ressemblent; dans une autre Planete, c'est une autre Famille dont les visages ont un autre air. <UP></UP>.</P051> <P052>Apparemment les differences augmentent à mesure que l'on s'éloigne, & qui verroit un Habitant de la Lune, & un Habitant de la Terre, remarqueroit bien qu'ils seroient de deux Mondes plus voisions qu'un Habitant de la Terre & un Habitant de Saturne. Icy, <NCP>par exemple</NCP>, on a l'usage de la voix, ailleurs on ne parle que par signes, plus loin on ne parle point du tout. Icy le raisonnemét se forme entierement par l'experience; ailleurs l'experience y ajoûte fort peu de chose, plus loin les Vieillards n'en sçavent pas plus que les Enfants. Icy on se tourmente de l'avenir plus que du passé; plus loin on ne se tourmente ny de l'un ny de l'autre, & ceux-là ne sont peut-estre pas les plus malheureux. On dit qu'il pourroit bien nous manquer un sixiéme Sens naturel, qui nous aprendroit beaucoup de choses que nous ignorons. Ce sixiéme Sens est apparemment dans quelque autre Monde, où il manque quelqu'un des cinq que nous possedons. Peut-estre mesme y a-t-il effectivement un grand nombre de Sens naturels; mais dans le partage que nous avons fait avec les Habitans des autres Planetes, il ne nous en est écheu que cinq, dont nous nous contentons faute d'en connoistre d'autres. Nos Sciences ont de certaines bornes que l'Esprit humain n'a jamais pû passer; il y a un point où elles nous manquent tout à coup, le reste est pour d'autres Mondes, où quelque chose de ce que nous sçavons est inconnu. <RW>Cette Planete-cy</RW> joüit des douceurs de l'Amour, mais elle est toûjours desolée en plusieurs de ses parties par les fureurs de la Guerre. Dans une autre Planete on joüit d'une Paix éternelle, mais au milieu de cette Paix on ne connoist point l'Amour, & on s'ennuye. Enfin ce que la Nature pratique en petit entre les hommes pour la distribution du bonheur où des talens, elle l'aura sans doute pratiqué en grand entre les Mondes, & elle se sera bien souvenuë de mettre en usage ce secret merveilleux qu'elle a de diversifier toutes choses, & de les égaler en mesme temps que les compensations.</P052>
chunks.target_manual: <P038>To conclude, every thing lives, and every thing is animated; that is to say, if you comprehend the Animals, that are generally known; the living Creatures lately discover'd, and those that will be discover'd herafter, you will find that the Earth is very well Peopl'd; and that Nature has been so liberal in bestowing them, that she has not been at the pains to discover half of 'em. After this, can you believe, that Nature, who has been fruitful to Excess as to the Earth, is barren to all the rest of the Planets? My Reason is convinc'd, said the Marquiese, but my Fancy in confounded with the infinite Number of living Creatures, that are in the Planets; and my thoughts are strangely embarass'd with the variety that one must of Necessity imagine to be amongst 'em; because I know Nature does not love Repetitions; and therefore they must all be different. But how is it possible for one to represent all these to our Fancy? Our Imaginations can never comprehend this variety, said I, let us be satisfied with our Eyes, or we may easily conceive by an universal view, Nature has form'd variety in the several Worlds. All the Faces of Mankind are in general near the same Form. Yet the two great Nations of our Globe, the Europaeans and Africans, seem to have been made after different Models. Nay, there is a certain resemblance and Air of the Countenance peculiar to every Family or Race of Men. Yet it is wonderful to observe how many Millions of Times, Nature has varied so simple a thing as the Face of a Man. We, the Inhabitants of the Earth, are but one little Family of the Universe, we resemble one another. The Inhabitants of another Planet, are another Family, whose Faces have another Air peculiar to themselves; by all appearance, the difference increases with the distance, for cou'd one see an Inhabitant of the Earth, and one of the Moon together, he wou'd perceive less difference between them, than between an Inhabitant of the Earth, and an Inhabitant of Saturn. Here <NCP>(for Example)</NCP> we have the use of the Tongue and Voice, and in another Planet, it may be, they only speak by Signs. In another the Inhabitants speaks not at all. Here our Reason is form'd and made perfect by Experience. In another Place, Experience adds little or nothing to Reason. Further off, the old know no more than the young. Here we trouble our selves more to know what's to come, than to know what's past. In another Planet, they neither afflict themselves with the one nor the other; and 'tis likely they are not the less happy for that. Some say we want a sixth Sense by which we shou'd know a great many things we are now ignorant of. It may be the Inhabitants of some other Planet have this advantage; but want some of those other five we enjoy; it may be also that there are a great many more natural Senses in other Worlds; but we are satisfi'd with the five that are fal'n to our Share, because we know no better. Our Knowledge is bounded to certain limits, which the Wit of Man cou'd never yet exceed. There is a certain point where our Ingenuity is at a stand; that which is beyond it is for some other World, where it may be some things, that are familiar to us, are altogether unknown. Our <RW>Globe</RW> enjoys the Pleasure of Love; but is destroyed in several places by the fury of War. Another Planet enjoys constant Peace, without the delights of Love, which must render their Lives very irksom. In fine, Nature has done to the several Worlds in great, as she has done to us Mortals in little by making some happy, others miserable. <UP>Yet she has never forgot her admirable Art</UP> in varying all things, tho she has made some equal in some respects, by compensating the want of any one thing, with another of equal value.</P038>

explanations: This entire introductory passage is added by the translator. It is not present in the provided source segment P051. It appears to be the philosopher (narrator) concluding a previous point and posing a rhetorical question before the Marquise begins to speak, thereby providing a conversational lead-in and context for her subsequent statement.
The translator added 'of our Globe' to specify that the 'two great Nations' (Europeans and Africans) being discussed are terrestrial, providing explicit geographical context for the reader.

The source's statement about needing to find models for family faces ('il faudroit encore trouver') is transformed by the translator into an affirmative observation ('Nay, there is a certain resemblance...'). The phrases 'Air of the Countenance peculiar to' and 'Race of Men' (for 'Famille') are elaborations that add descriptive detail and specificity.

The translator transformed the source's rhetorical question ('Quel secret...') into an exclamatory expression of awe ('Yet it is wonderful to observe'). Furthermore, 'how many Millions of Times' is a significant hyperbolic elaboration of the source's more general 'en tant de manieres' (in so many ways), intensifying the marvel expressed.
The translator replaced the French pronoun 'Nous' (We) with the explicit noun phrase 'the Inhabitants of the Earth,' to remove ambiguity and clearly identify the group being referred to.

The source's 'un autre air' (another air/look) is elaborated by the translator to 'peculiar to themselves,' which emphasizes the distinctiveness and unique individuality of the facial features of inhabitants on other planets.

The source refers to 'l'usage de la voix' (the use of the voice). The translator added 'Tongue and' to make the mechanism of speech more concrete by specifying the organ used, a common English formulation.

The source states reason 'se forme entierement' (is formed entirely/completely) by experience. The translator’s addition of 'and made perfect' introduces a qualitative outcome, suggesting experience not only forms but also refines reason to an ideal state.

The source states the sixth sense 'est apparemment dans quelque autre Monde' (is apparently in some other world). The target's phrasing 'have this advantage;' interprets the possession of this sense as a clear benefit, an explicit positive valuation not present in the source.

The source says 'que nous possedons' (that we possess). The translator’s choice of 'we enjoy' adds a positive experiential and affective connotation to the possession of the five senses, which is an interpretative addition.

The source states 'on ne connoist point l'Amour' (one does not know Love). The translator added 'without the delights of Love,' which specifies what is absent by not knowing love, framing it in terms of 'delights' and adding emotional context.

The source simply states '& on s'ennuye' (and one gets bored / and they get bored). The translator significantly expanded this into 'which must render their Lives very irksom,' elaborating the feeling of boredom into a more impactful and negative condition affecting their entire existence.
The source uses 'entre les hommes' (among men/humans). The translator's addition of 'to us Mortals' specifies humans by their mortal nature, adding a slightly more philosophical or literary nuance.

The source refers to 'la distribution du bonheur où des talens' (the distribution of happiness or talents). The translator reinterprets this as 'by making some happy, others miserable,' creating a starker, more dramatic binary outcome of Nature's distribution and adding the concept of 'miserable'.

The source's 'elle se sera bien souvenuë de mettre en usage ce secret merveilleux qu'elle a' (she will have well remembered to put to use this marvelous secret that she has) is rendered as 'Yet she has never forgot her admirable Art'. This personifies Nature more strongly with 'her admirable Art' and uses the more emphatic 'never forgot', changing the tone and emphasis.

The source concisely states '& de les égaler en mesme temps que les compensations' (and to make them equal at the same time by/through compensations). The translator has significantly elaborated on this by adding phrases like 'tho she has made some equal in some respects,' 'the want of any one thing,' and 'with another of equal value,' which explain the mechanism of compensation in much greater detail.

chunks.source_manual: <P053>Etes-vous contente, Madame, ajoûtay-je en quittant le ton serieux? Vous ay-je dubité assez de chimeres? Vrayment, répondit-elle, il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences de tous ces Mondes. Mon imagination travaille sur le plan que vous m'avez donné. Je me represente comme je puis des Caracteres & des Coûtumes extraordinaire pour les Habitans des Planetes, & je leur compose mesme des figures tout-à-fait bizarres. Je ne vous les pourrois pas décrire, mais je voy pourtant quelque chose. Pour ces figures-là, repliquay-je, je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin aux Songes que vous aurez cette nuit. Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.</P053>
chunks.target_manual: <P039>Are you satisfi'd, said I, Madam, very gravely; have not I told you Chimeras in abundance? Truly, I find not so much difficulty to comprehend these differences of Worlds; my Imagination is working upon the Model you have given me And I am representing to my own Mind odd Characters and Customs for these Inhabitants of the other Planets. Nay more, I am forming extravagant shapes and figures for 'em: I can describe 'em to you; for I fansie I see 'em here. I leave these shapes, said I, Madam, to entertain you in Dreams this Night, to morrow, we shall know, if they have assisted you, to describe the Inhabitants of some other Planet.</P039>

explanations: The source text states the philosopher spoke 'en quittant le ton serieux' (leaving the serious tone), implying a shift to a lighter manner. The translator replaced this with 'very gravely,' which means speaking in a very serious manner. This introduces a description of the speaker's tone that is the opposite of the original, and thus 'very gravely' is new information not present in (and contradictory to) the source.

The translator added the conjunction 'And' at the beginning of this clause. The source text starts a new sentence here ('Je me represente...') without a coordinating conjunction. 'And' was likely added to create a smoother narrative flow in English, linking this part of the Marquise's speech more explicitly to her preceding statement.

This phrase is added as a discourse marker to introduce an escalation in the Marquise's imaginative process. While the source uses 'mesme' (even) as an intensifier within its clause, 'Nay more,' functions as a separate introductory element in English, making the transition more explicit and emphatic for the target reader.

The translator inverted the meaning of the source text. The original states the Marquise *cannot* describe the figures ('Je ne vous les pourrois pas décrire'). The target text introduces the opposite proposition: 'I can describe 'em to you'. This new affirmative proposition is added, fundamentally altering the Marquise's stated ability.

The source uses 'mais' (but) to connect the Marquise's inability to describe figures with her still seeing something. The translation, having already changed the preceding clause to an ability to describe, introduces this clause with 'for'. The addition of 'for' (and omission of 'mais') changes the logical relationship from contrast to causality, providing a reason for her newly asserted ability to describe the figures.

The translator added 'here.' to specify the locus of the Marquise's imagined vision, making it more immediate and present ('I fansie I see 'em right here/now'). The source text's 'je voy pourtant quelque chose' (I see something nonetheless) is less specific about the immediacy or location of this vision. The period is part of the segment as it appears in the target text.

The source text has the philosopher advising the Marquise ('je vous conseille') to entrust the imagining of figures to her dreams. The translation changes this to a direct statement by the philosopher: 'I leave these shapes...', implying he is the one consigning these matters to her dreams. This shifts the agency and the nature of the speech act from advice to a declaration of his own action.

The source text suggests leaving the 'care' (le soin) of the figures to dreams. The translator added 'to entertain you' to specify the purpose or function of these dreams from the Marquise's perspective, framing them as a source of amusement or diversion, a nuance not explicitly present in the source.

The source states that they will see if the dreams 'vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants' (will have taught you how the Inhabitants are made/formed). The target text changes this to whether the dreams 'have assisted you, to describe the Inhabitants...'. The addition of 'to describe' shifts the outcome from gaining knowledge about the inhabitants' nature to gaining or being assisted in the ability to articulate or depict them.

chunks.source_manual: <P054>QUATRIEME SOIR.</P054>
chunks.target_manual: <P040>The Fourth Night.</P040>

chunks.source_manual: <P055><SC>Les songes ne furent point heureux: ils representerent toûjours quelque chose qui ressembloit à ce que l'on voit icy. J'eus lieu de reprocher à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM> ce que nous reprochent à la veüe de nos Tableaux, de certains Peuples qui ne font jamaïs que des peintures bizarres & grotesques. Bon, nous disent-ils, cela est tout fait comme des hommes, il n'y a pas là d'imagination. Il falut donc se resoudre à ignorer les figures des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & se contenter d'en deviner ce que nous pourrions, en continuant le Voyage des Mondes que nous avions commencé.</SC> Nous en estions à Venus. On est bien seur, dis-je à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que Venus tourne sur elle-mesme, <SC>mais on ne sçait pas bien en quel temps</SC>, ny par consequent combien ses jours durent. Pour ses années, elles ne sont que de huit mois, puis qu'elle tourne en ce temps-là autour du Soleil. Come elle est quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, la Terre de dedans Venus paroist une Planete quarante fois plus grande, que Venus ne nous paroist d'icy; & comme la Lune est aussi quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, elle paroist dedans Venus à peu prés de la mesme grandeur dont Venus nous paroist d'icy.</P055>
chunks.target_manual: <P041>THe Dreams <UP>of my Lady Marquiese</UP> were not lucky, they still represented to her something like what we see on Earth; so that I had as much reason to reproach her, as certain People have to blame us when they see some of our Pictures; for they being ignorant of drawing, and designing, and pleasing themselves with their extravagant and grotesque Figures, tell us, our Pictures are nothing but Men and Women, and that there is no Fancy in 'em; there was therefore a necessity of laying aside all sorts of the Forms and Figures of those Animals that inhabit several Planets, and to rest satisfy'd by guessing as well as we can, in pursuing our Journey, which we had begun, through the several Worlds of the Universe.</P041> <P042>We were at Venus: And there is no doubt, said I to my Lady Marquiese, but Venus turns upon her own Axis, but 'tis not known in what time, and by consequence, we know not the length of her Days, but her Years must consist but of eight Months, since Venus turns round the Sun <UP>in that space of time</UP>. As Venus is forty times less than the Earth, the Earth must necessarily appear to the Inhabitants of Venus, to be forty times bigger than Venus appears to us; and as the Moon is also forty times less than the Earth, by consequence, it must appear to the Inhabitants of Venus, about the same bigness that Venus appears to us.</P042>

explanations: The translator added 'of my Lady Marquiese' to explicitly identify whose dreams are being discussed and to use a common English honorific ('my Lady'), providing clarity and cultural normalization for the English reader where the source text ('Les songes' - The dreams) relies on context for the possessor.
The translator added 'to her' to explicitly state that the dreams represented things *to the Marquise*, enhancing clarity where the source text ('ils representerent') implies the recipient.

The translator added the clause 'for they being ignorant of drawing, and designing, and pleasing themselves with their extravagant and grotesque Figures,' to provide an explanation for why the 'certain Peoples' criticize conventional art and prefer 'bizarre & grotesques' paintings. This rationale is not present in the source text, which only describes their actions and preferences.

The translator added 'of the Universe' to 'Worlds' ('Mondes'), elaborating on the scope of the 'Voyage des Mondes' and adding a sense of cosmic scale that, while implied, is not explicit in the source.

The translator added 'my Lady' when rendering 'à la Marquise' as 'to my Lady Marquiese'. This is a cultural normalization, adding an English honorific not directly present in the French 'à la Marquise' (to the Marquise).

The translator replaced the general phrase 'sur elle-mesme' (on herself) with the more specific and scientific term 'upon her own Axis.' This addition enhances technical precision and clarity, aligning with the nature of a work popularizing science.
The translator elaborated 'en ce temps-là' (in that time/then) into 'in that space of time.' This addition emphasizes the duration, making the temporal aspect more explicit or formal in English.

The translator added 'to the Inhabitants of Venus' to clarify who perceives the Earth from Venus. The source 'la Terre de dedans Venus paroist' (the Earth from within Venus appears) is less explicit about the observer.

The translator added the logical connector 'by consequence,' modifying the clause that describes the Moon's appearance from Venus. The source text begins the sentence with '& comme...' (and as/since...), implying a logical link; this addition makes the inferential step more explicit.

Similar to the previous instance concerning the Earth, the translator added 'to the Inhabitants of Venus' to clarify who perceives the Moon from Venus. The source 'elle paroist dedans Venus' (it appears from within Venus) is less explicit about the observer.

chunks.source_manual: <P056>Vous m'affligez, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Je voy bien que la Terre n'est pas pour Vénus l'Etoile du Berger, & la Mere des Amours, comme Vénus l'est pour la Terre; car la Terre de dedans Vénus paroist trop grande, mais la Lune qui y paroist de la mesme grandeur dont Vénus nous paroist d'icy, est justement taillée comme il faut pour y estre Mere des Amours, & Etoile du Berger <NCE></NCE>. Ces noms ne peuvent convenir qu'à une petite Planete qui soit jolie, claire, brillante, & qui ait un air galant. <UP></UP> C'est asseurément une destinée agréable pour nostre Lune que de presider aux Amours des Habitans de Venus; ces Gens là doivent bien entendre la galanterie. Oh! sans doute, répondis-je, le menu Peuple de Venus n'est composé que de Celadons & de Silvandres, & leurs Conversations le plus communes valent les plus belles de Clesie. <UP></UP> Le climat est tres-favorable aux Amours. Venus est plus proche que nous du Soleil, & elle en reçoit une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur.</P056> <P057>Je vois presentement, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, comment sont faits les Habitans de Venus. Ils ressemblent aux Mores Grenadins; un petit Peuple noir, brûlé du Soleil, plein d'esprit & de feu, toûjours amoureux, faisant des Vers, aimant la Musique, inventant tous les jours des Festes, des Danses, & des Tournois. Permettez-moy de vous dire, Madame, repliquay-je, que vous ne connoissez guere bien les Habitans de Venus. Nos Mores Grenadins n'auroient esté auprés d'eux que des Lappons & des Groënlandois pour la froideur & pour la stupidité.</P057>
chunks.target_manual: <P043>You afflict me, said the Marquiese <UP>, extremely</UP>; I see very well, that our Earth is not <IIM>that happy Planet to the Inhabitants of</IIM> Venus, as she is to us; for our Globe of the Earth must appear too big to the Inhabitants of Venus, to be the <IIM>Fountain</IIM> of Love, but the Moon, which appears to the World of Venus, of the same size that Venus appears to us, is exactly cut out to be <UP>the Source of their Amours, and the lucky Star of their Intrigues</UP>; which Titles are most agreeable to the pretty, clear, twinkling Planets, which have in 'em a certain Air of Gallantry. 'Tis certainly a happy Fate for our Moon to give Laws to the Loves of the Inhabitants of Venus: No doubt, but these People are very soft, and have the Art to please extreamly well. Without dispute, Madam, said I; the very Mobile of Venus are all made up of Celladons and Silvanders, and their most ordinary Conversations excel the finest in Clelia; the Climate being more savourable to Love: Venus being nearer the Sun than we, receives from its Influence a brighter Light, and a more enlivening Heat. I perceive very well, interrupted the Marquiese, what kind of People the Inhabitants of Venus are; they are, like our Moors of Granada, a sort of little Sun-burnt Gentlemen, always in Love, full of Life and Fire, given to making Verses, and great Lovers of Musick, and every Day inventing Feasts, Balls and Masquerades, to entertain their Mistresses. Pray, Madam, said I, you are very ill acquainted with the Inhabitants of Venus; for our Moors of Granada are, in respect to them, as the Inhabitants of Lapland, or Greenland, for Coldness and Stupidity.</P043>

explanations: The translator added 'extremely' to intensify the Marquise's statement, making her distress more pronounced for the English reader.

The translator added the clause 'to be the Fountain of Love' to explicitly state the consequence of Earth's large size as seen from Venus, linking it directly to its unsuitability as the 'Mother of Loves' (rendered 'Fountain of Love' by the translator). The source implies this connection but doesn't state it as a direct causal outcome in this part of the sentence.
The translator replaced the pronoun 'y' (there) with the more explicit phrase 'to the World of Venus' to clarify the location for the English reader, enhancing comprehension.

The translator added 'of their Intrigues' when rendering 'Etoile du Berger' (Shepherd's Star). While 'lucky Star' is an interpretation, 'of their Intrigues' introduces a specific type of romantic activity not present in the original, adding a layer of sophisticated connotation.

The translator used the phrase 'to give Laws to the Loves' as a rendition of 'presider aux Amours' (to preside over the Loves). This is a stronger, more active phrasing, adding the nuance of a governing or controlling influence not as explicitly present in the source.

The translator significantly elaborated on 'doivent bien entendre la galanterie' (must well understand gallantry) by adding the descriptive phrase 'very soft, and have the Art to please extreamly well.' 'Very soft' introduces a new characteristic, and the rest embellishes the practical application of gallantry.
The translator added the polite term of address 'Madam,' which is conventional in English dialogues, making the conversation style more familiar to the target audience.

The translator added 'from its Influence' to elaborate on how Venus receives light and heat from the Sun (source: 'elle en reçoit' - 'it receives from it'). This addition specifies a mode of reception with a slightly more formal or philosophical nuance.

The translator added the adjective 'enlivening' to 'Heat,' qualifying it and suggesting a specific effect of the heat on Venus, which is not explicitly mentioned in the source's 'plus de chaleur' (more heat).

The translator added 'Gentlemen' to the description of the Venusians (source: 'un petit Peuple noir' - a small, dark people). This term elevates their social standing and refines their image for the English audience.

The translator added the intensifier 'great' before 'Lovers of Musick,' strengthening the description of the Venusians' fondness for music compared to the source's simpler 'aimant la Musique' (loving music).

The translator added 'and Masquerades' to the list of activities. The source lists 'Festes, Danses, & des Tournois' (Feasts, Dances, and Tournaments). The target has 'Feasts, Balls and Masquerades.' 'Masquerades' is a new type of event introduced, adapting cultural references, while 'Tournois' (Tournaments) from the source is omitted.

The translator added the clause 'to entertain their Mistresses' to specify the purpose of the festivities invented by the Venusians. The source text describes them inventing daily events but does not state for whom or why, so this addition strongly reinforces the amorous and gallant themes.

chunks.source_manual: <P058>Mais que sera-ce des Habitants de Mercure? Ils sont encore plus proches du Soleil; il faut qu'ils soient fous à force de vivacité. <UP></UP> Je croy qu'ils n'ont point de memoire, non plus que la plupart des Négres; qu'ils ne font jamais de reflexion sur rien, qu'ils n'agissent qu'à l'aventure, & par des mouvemens subits, & <IIM>qu'enfin c'est dans Mercure que sont les Petites Maisons de l'Univers.</IIM> <NCE></NCE> Ils voyent le Soleil beaucoup plus grand que nous ne le voyons, parce qu'ils en sont beaucoup plus proches. Il leur envoye une lumiere si forte, que s'ils estoient icy, ils ne prendroient nos plus beaux jours que pour de <IIM>tres-foibles</IIM> Crepuscules, & peut-estre n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets, & la chaleur à laquelle ils sont accoûtumez est si excessive, que celle qu'il fait icy au fond de l'Afrique, suffiroit pour les glacier. Leur année n'est que de trois mois. La durée de leur jour ne nous est point encore connuë, parce que Mercure est si petit & si proche du Soleil, dans les rayons duquel il est presque toûjours perdu, qu'il échappe à toute l'adresse des Astronomes, & qu'on n'a pû encore avoir assez de prise sur luy, pour observer le mouvement qu'il doit avoir sur son centre; mais sa petitesse fait croire qu'il acheve ce tour en peu de temps; que par consequent le jour de Mercure est fort court, & que les Habitans voyent le Soleil comme un <RW>grand poêle ardent</RW>, peu éloigné de leurs testes, & qui va d'une rapidité prodigieuse. Cela en est mieux pour eux, car apparemment ils soûpirent aprés la nuit. Ils sont éclairez pendant ce temps-là de Venus,& de la Terre, qui leur doivent paroistre assez grandes. Pour les autres Planetes, comme elles sont au-delà de la <IIM>Terre vers le Firmament</IIM>, ils les voyent plus petites que nous ne les voyons, & n'en reçoivent que bien peu de lumiere, peut-estre n'en reçoivent-ils point du tout. Les Etoles Fixes sont aussi plus petites pour eux, & même il doit y en avoir beaucoup qui disparoissent entierement; c'est, selon moy, une perte. Je suis bien fàché de voir cette <RW>grande voûte ornée de mois d'Etoiles, & de ne voir celles qui me resteroient</RW>, que plus petites, & d'une couleur plus effacée. <SC></SC>.</P058>
chunks.target_manual: <P044>But what then must the Inhabitants of Mercury be, for they are yet more near to the Sun? They must certainly be mad, by having too much Light and Fire; and I believe they have no more Memory, than the most part of our Negroes; they never think, and are void of all Reflection, and they only act by Chance, and by sudden Impulses. In short, the Planet Mercury <IIM>must certainly be the Bethlem</IIM> of the Universe; they see the Sun a great deal bigger than we do, because they are so much nearer to it; he darts upon 'em so strong a Light, that if the Inhabitants of Venus were here, they wou'd take our finest Days for the Remains of a <IIM>saint</IIM> Twi-light; and it may be, the Light we enjoy, wou'd not serve them to distinguish one Object from another; and the Heat they are accustom'd to is so excessive, that the greatest warmth enjoy'd by the Inhabitants of the middle of Africk, wou'd frieze them to death. Their Year casts but three Months; the length of their Day is yet unknown, Mercury being so little a Planet, and so near the Sun, in whose Rays he is so continually lost, that he is hitherto scarce discoverable by <RW>the Art and Skill of</RW> Astronomers, who cou'd never yet get so much hold of Mercury, as to observe the Time in which he performs his Revolution <RW>upon his own Axis</RW> or Centre; but the smallness <UP>of his Planet</UP> perswades me 'tis in a very short time, and then, by consequence, his Days are very short, and his Inhabitants must see the Sun <RW>as a very great flaming Brasier</RW>, very near their Heads, which, to their Apprehension, moves with wonderful Rapidity; this makes them so earnestly wish for the coming Night, which, no doubt, must be much more grateful to 'em than the Day; and during those cooler Hours, they are enlightned by Venus, and by the Earth; which two Planets must appear to them of considerable bigness. As for the other Planets, since they are remov'd further than <IIM>Mercury </IIM>, towards the Firmament, his Inhabitants must see them less than they appear to us, and receive but little Light from 'em, it may be, none at all; the fixed Stars must appear less to 'em also, and they lose the sight of some of 'em entirely, which, in my Opinion, is a very great Loss; for I shou'd be very sorry to see <RW>the vast arch'd Roof of the Heavens</RW> adorn'd with fewer Stars, or those I do see, appear less, and not so bright.</P044>

explanations: The source attributes their madness to 'vivacité' (vivacity/liveliness). The translator elaborates by rendering this cause as 'by having too much Light and Fire,' making the source of Mercury's heat (and thus the cause of madness related to the Sun) more explicit.

The source refers to 'des Négres' (Negroes/some Negroes). The addition of 'our' personalizes the reference for the English audience of the time, possibly evoking a colonial context familiar to them and changing 'des' (of the/some) to a possessive.

The source 'qu'ils ne font jamais de reflexion sur rien' (they never make any reflection on anything) is primarily translated as 'void of all Reflection'. The phrase 'they never think, and are' is added before this, creating a doublet that emphasizes the lack of cognitive processes.

'Les Petites Maisons' was a French term for an insane asylum. The translator substitutes this with 'Bethlem' (Bedlam), its well-known English equivalent, to provide immediate cultural relevance and understanding for the target audience.

The source's pronoun 'ils' (they) refers to the inhabitants of Mercury. The translator changes the referent to 'the Inhabitants of Venus,' introducing a new subject into the comparison that is not present in the original French text.

The source describes Earth's brightest days as 'de tres-foibles Crepuscules' (very faint twilights) for the inhabitants in question. The target text alters this to 'the Remains of a saint Twi-light.' 'The Remains of a' is an elaboration, and 'saint' is a specific adjective not derived from 'tres-foibles,' changing the imagery significantly.

The source 'n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets' (they couldn't distinguish objects there/with it) is rephrased and expanded. The translator adds 'the Light we enjoy' to specify the implicit instrument ('y') and changes the construction to 'wou'd not serve them' for clarity.

The source refers to 'celle [la chaleur] qu'il fait icy au fond de l'Afrique' (the [heat] that it is here in the depths of Africa). The translator adds the participial phrase 'enjoy'd by the Inhabitants of' to explicitly link the experience of this heat to people.

The source 'suffiroit pour les glacier' means 'would be enough to freeze them.' The translator adds the intensifier 'to death' after 'frieze' (freeze), making the fatal outcome explicit using a common English collocation.

The source states 'parce que Mercure est si petit' (because Mercury is so small). The translator adds 'a Planet' (target: 'so little a Planet') to explicitly clarify that Mercury is being discussed in its capacity as a planet.

The source mentions 'l'adresse des Astronomes' (the skill/cleverness of astronomers). The translator renders 'adresse' as 'Art and Skill.' The addition of 'Art and' creates a doublet, a common rhetorical device for emphasis or to attempt to capture a broader meaning.

The source refers to Mercury's movement 'sur son centre' (on its center). The translator clarifies 'centre' by rendering it as 'Axis or Centre,' with 'Axis or' being the added element for astronomical precision.
The source 'mais sa petitesse' (but its smallness) is made more specific by the addition of 'of his Planet,' clarifying that 'sa' (its) refers to Mercury the planet.

The source 'fait croire' (makes one believe/suggests) is an impersonal construction. The translator personalizes this by rendering it as 'perswades me,' explicitly inserting the narrator's viewpoint ('me').

The source describes the sun's movement as having 'une rapidité prodigieuse' (a prodigious rapidity). The translator adds the phrase 'to their Apprehension,' before 'moves with wonderful Rapidity' to specify that this perceived speed is from the specific perspective of these inhabitants.

The source 'ils soûpirent aprés la nuit' (they sigh/long for the night) is rendered as 'they ... wish for the coming Night'. The translator adds 'so earnestly' to intensify the verb 'wish', an emphasis not present in 'soûpirent'.

This entire clause, 'which, no doubt, must be much more grateful to 'em than the Day;', which provides a comparative reason for longing for the night, is a new proposition added by the translator and is not present in the source text which only states they long for night.

The source 'pendant ce temps-là' (during that time) refers to the night on Mercury. The translator adds the descriptive phrase 'cooler Hours' to specify the qualitative nature of this time, providing context by inferring contrast to Mercury's hot days.

The source uses the relative pronoun 'qui' (which/that) to refer back to Venus and Earth. The translator adds 'two Planets' (target: 'which two Planets') to make the antecedent explicit for the reader.

The source states the other planets are 'au-delà de la Terre' (beyond the Earth). The target text changes this point of reference by stating they are 'remov'd further than Mercury.' This phrase introduces a different comparative basis not in the source.
The source uses the pronoun 'ils' (they) referring to the inhabitants of Mercury. The translator makes this explicit by replacing 'ils' with 'his Inhabitants' (Mercury's inhabitants) for clarity.
The source states 'une perte' (a loss). The translator adds the intensifier 'a very great' before 'Loss,' to emphasize the narrator's feeling about this.

The source describes 'cette grande voûte' (this great vault). The translator expands this with the more elaborate and poetic phrase 'the vast arch'd Roof of the Heavens.' The words 'vast' and 'arch'd Roof of the Heavens' are additions that embellish the original simpler description.

chunks.source_manual: <P059>Je ne suis pas si touchée, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, de cette perte-là que sont les <IIM>Habitans de Mercure</IIM>, que de l'incommodité qu'ils reçoivent de l'excés de la chaleur. Je voudrois bien que nous les soulageassions un peu. Donnons à Mercure de longues & d'abondantes pluyes qui le rafraischissent, comme on dit qu'il en tombe icy dans les Pays chauds pendant des quatre mois entiers, justement dans les saisons les plus chaudes.</P059> <P060>Cela se peut, repris-je, & mesme nous pouvons rafraîchir encore Mercure d'une autre façon. Il y a des Pays dans la Chine qui doivent estre tres-chauds par leur situation, & où il fait pourtant de grands froids pendant les mois de Juillet & d'Aoust, jusque-là que les Rivieres se gelent. C'est que ces contrées là ont beaucoup de Salpêtre; les exhalaisons en sont fort froides, & la force de la chaleur les fait sortir de la Terre en grande abondance. Mercure sera, si vous voulez, une petite Planete toute de <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM>, & le Soleil tirera d'elle-mesme le remede au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire. Ce qu'il y a de seur, c'est que la Nature ne sçauroit faire vivre les Gens qu'où ils peuvent vivre, & que l'habitude jointe à l'ignorance de quelque chose de meilleur, survient, & les y fait vivre agréablement. Ainsi on pourroit même se passer dans Mercure du <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM> & des pluyes.</P060>
chunks.target_manual: <P045>I am not so much concern'd for that Loss, said the Marquiese, as for <IIM>their</IIM> being so extreamly incommoded with excessive Heat; and I wish with all my heart, we cou'd ease 'em of that Trouble. Let us therefore allow 'em long and continued Rain, to refresh 'em; such as are in some of the hot Countries of our Earth, which fall for four Months together, during the hottest Seasons. That may be done, said I; but we may find out another Remedy, to relieve the Inhabitants of Mercury; for there are Countries in China, which, by their Situation, must be very hot; yet notwithstanding, the Cold is so excessive during the Months of Iuly and August, that the Rivers are frozen: The Reason is, These Climates abound with <IIM>Salt-Petre </IIM> (whose Exhalations being very cold) the force of the Heat draws out of the Earth in great abundance. Let us therefore suppose Mercury to be a little Planet, made of <IIM>Salt-Petre </IIM>; and let the Sun extract out of himself a Remedy to his Disease which he gives to the Inhabitants. This is certain, that Nature produces no Animal, but in places where they may live; and Custom and Use, joined with Ignorance of what is better, supplieth all Defects, and makes Life agreeable; for ought we know, the Inhabitants of Mercury want neither Rain, nor Exhalations of <IIM>Salt-Petre</IIM>.</P045>

explanations: The translator added 'with all my heart' to emphasize the Marquise's sentiment and make her concern more expressive for the English audience, where the source 'Je voudrois bien ... un peu' is more subdued.

The translator added 'therefore' to create a more explicit logical connection between the Marquise's previously expressed wish to ease the inhabitants' trouble and the proposed solution of rain. The source 'Donnons à Mercure' does not have this explicit connective.

The translator added 'of our Earth' to explicitly clarify that 'icy' (here) in the source refers to Earth, providing necessary context for English readers who might not immediately make that connection.

The translator added 'to relieve the Inhabitants of Mercury' to explicitly state the purpose and beneficiary of the 'other Remedy.' The source states '& mesme nous pouvons rafraîchir encore Mercure d'une autre façon' (and we can even cool Mercury further in another way), focusing on the planet, while the addition shifts focus to the inhabitants' relief.

The translator added 'The Reason is,' to explicitly introduce the explanation for the cold in hot Chinese climates. The source 'C'est que ces contrées là ont beaucoup de Salpêtre' (It's that these regions have a lot of Saltpeter) implies causality, but the addition makes the explanatory function of the sentence clearer.

The translator added 'therefore' to create a stronger logical link between the preceding discussion of saltpeter's cooling properties in China and the subsequent proposal to 'suppose Mercury to be a little Planet, made of Salt-Petre.' The source 'Mercure sera, si vous voulez...' lacks this explicit sequential logic.

The translator added the clause 'which he gives to the Inhabitants.' The source phrase '& le Soleil tirera d'elle-mesme le remede au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire' indicates the Sun could do harm ('mal') to Mercury ('luy'). The addition specifies that this 'Disease' (the translator's interpretation of 'mal') is given by the Sun directly to the inhabitants, an elaboration not present in the source.

The translator expanded the French 'l'habitude' (habit or custom) into the English doublet 'Custom and Use.' The addition of 'and Use' is a common rhetorical device in English to elaborate or intensify the meaning of a single term, making the concept more familiar or emphatic for the target audience.

The translator added the phrase 'supplieth all Defects,' which is an explanatory elaboration not present in the source. The source states that habit and ignorance 'survient, & les y fait vivre agréablement' (comes along/intervenes, and makes them live there agreeably); the addition explains *how* they make life agreeable by suggesting they compensate for deficiencies.

The translator added the introductory phrase 'for ought we know,'. The source 'Ainsi on pourroit même se passer dans Mercure du Salpêtre & des pluyes' (Thus one could even do without saltpeter and rains in Mercury) is a more direct assertion. The addition introduces a degree of speculation or epistemological modesty to the statement.

The translator added 'Exhalations of' before 'Salt-Petre.' The source simply states 'du Salpêtre & des pluyes' (of saltpeter and rains). This addition refers back to the earlier mention of 'Exhalations being very cold' from saltpeter, thereby specifying the particular aspect of saltpeter that might be unnecessary.

chunks.source_manual: <P061>Aprés Mercure vous sçavez qu'on trouve le Soleil. Il n'y a pas moyen d'y mettre d'Habitans. Le Pourquoy non nous manque-là. Nous jugeons par la Terre qui est habitée, que les autres Corps de la mesme espece qu'elle, doivent l'estre aussi; mais le Soleil n'est point un Corps de la mesme espece que la Terre, ny que les autres Planetes. Il est la source de toute cette lumiere que les Planetes ne font que se renvoyer les unes aux autres, aprés l'avoir reçeüe de luy. Elles ne peuvent faire, pour ainsi dire, des échanges entre elles, mais elles ne la peuvent produire. Luy seul tire de soy-mesme cette pretieuse substance; il la pousse avec force de tous costez; de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide, & d'une Planete à l'autre il s'épand de longues & vastes traisnées de lumieres qui se croisent & se traversent, & s'entrelassent en mille façons diferentes, & forment d'admirables tissus de la plus riche matiere qui soit au monde. Aussi le Soleil est-il placé dans le centre, qui est le lieu le plus commode d'où il la puisse distribuer également, & animer tout par sa chaleur <NCP></NCP>. Le Soleil est donc un Corps <UP>particulier</UP>, mais quelle sorte de Corps? On est bien embarrassé à le dire. On avoit toûjours crû que c'estoit un feu tres-pur, mais on s'en desabusa au commencement de ce <IIM>Siecle</IIM>, qu'on apperceut des taches sur sa surface. Comme on avoit découvert peu de temps auparavant de nouvelles Planetes dont je vous parleray; que tout le <IIM>Monde Philosophe</IIM> n'avoit l'esprit remply d'autre chose, & qu'enfin les nouvelles Planetes s'estoient mises à la mode, on jugea aussi-tost que ces taches en estoient; <UP>qu'elles avoyent un mouvement autour du Soleil</UP>, & qu'elles nous en cachoient necessairement quelque partie, en tournant leur moitié obscure vers nous. Déja les Sçavans faisoient leur Cour de ces pretendües Planetes à tous les Princes de l'Europe. Les uns leur donnoient le nom d'un Prince, les autres d'un autre, & peut-estre il y auroit eu querelle entre-eux à qui seroit demeuré le maistre des taches pour les nommer comme il eust voulu...</P061>
chunks.target_manual: <P046>After Mercury, you know, the next Planet we find in our Journey, is the Sun; and if we judge by the Earth <NCP>(which is inhabited)</NCP> that other Bodies of the same kind may be so too, we are mistaken, and the Why not will fail us here; for the Sun is a Body of a quite different Nature from the Earth, and other Planets: He is the Source and Fountain of all that Light, which the other Planets do only reflect from one to another, after having receiv'd it from him; and so they can exchange Light one with another, but are incapable of producing it: The Sun alone draws from it self this precious Substance, which he darts a-round him with great Force and Violence, and which is intercepted by every Body that is solid; so that there is reflected from one Planet to another long streams and streaks of Light, which crossing and traversing each other in the Air, are interwoven a thousand different Ways, and so form a Mixture of the richest substance in Nature: For this end the Sun is plac'd in the Centre, which is the Situation most proper and commode; from whence he may equally dispense and distribute his Light and Heat, for the livening and enlightning all things round him. The Sun is therefore a Body of a particular Substance; but what kind of Body, or what kind of Substance, is all the difficulty: Heretofore 'twas believ'd, that the Sun was a pure Fire; but the Error of this Opinion was found out in the Beginning of this Age, by Spots which were discover'd upon the Surface of the Sun; as a little after that time, there were new Planets discover'd, of which I shall speak hereafter: The learned part of the World were full of nothing else but these new Planets; and Discourses of 'em were so much in fashion, that they believ'd the Spots in the Sun were nothing else but these new Planets, moving round 'em, which necessarily hid a part of his Body from our sight, when their obscure Side was turn'd towards us. The learned Men of the World made their Court to most Kings and Princes, with these new discover'd Planets; giving the Name of one Prince to one, and of another Prince to another; so that they were like to quarrel, to whom they shou'd belong.</P046>

explanations: The translator added 'the next Planet we find in our Journey,' to make the narrative context of their ongoing 'journey' through the planets more explicit for the reader. The source simply states 'one finds the Sun'.

The translator added 'we are mistaken,' to explicitly state the conclusion that applying Earth's analogy to the Sun is erroneous. The source text implies this mistake by contrasting the Sun's nature with Earth's but doesn't state it directly.

The translator added 'and Fountain' as a stylistic doublet to 'Source,' a common rhetorical device of the period, to emphasize the Sun's role as the origin of light. 'Source' and 'Fountain' are near-synonyms here.
The translator added 'and Violence' to 'Force,' creating a doublet. This intensifies the description of how the Sun emits light, a common stylistic choice in English translations of the era.

The translator added 'in the Air' to specify the medium through which the light rays travel and interact as they cross and interweave. The source text implies this but does not explicitly mention the location.

The translator used the doublet 'dispense and distribute' for the single French verb 'distribuer' (to distribute). This stylistic choice adds rhetorical emphasis to the Sun's action of spreading light and heat.

The source states the Sun animates everything with its heat ('animer tout par sa chaleur'). The target expands this to 'for the livening and enlightning all things round him.' While 'livening' corresponds to 'animer,' 'enlightning' is an addition, explicitly linking the Sun's light (previously mentioned for distribution) to its effect on surrounding things, alongside the animation by heat.

The translator added 'Substance' after 'Body' (French: 'Corps particulier'). This addition emphasizes the unique material nature or composition of the Sun, which is the subject of the subsequent question.

The source asks 'mais quelle sorte de Corps?' (but what kind of Body?). The translator expands this to 'but what kind of Body, or what kind of Substance,' making the inquiry more specific by including its composition ('Substance') as a distinct aspect to question, not just its type ('Body').

The source uses 'on s'en desabusa' (one was disabused of it/one realized the error). The translator makes this more explicit by adding 'the Error of this Opinion,' clearly stating what people were disabused of, thereby enhancing clarity.

The source states that 'the new planets had come into fashion' ('les nouvelles Planetes s'estoient mises à la mode,'). The translator elaborates by adding 'and Discourses of 'em,' specifying that it was the discussions about the planets that became fashionable, rather than just the planets themselves as abstract entities.

The source says 'les Sçavans' (the Scholars/Learned men). The translator adds 'of the World' to 'The learned Men,' likely to emphasize their broad, perhaps universal, intellectual community or to lend a more grandiose tone.

The source refers to 'tous les Princes de l'Europe' (all the Princes of Europe). The translator expands this to 'most Kings and Princes,' adding 'Kings and' to make the list of rulers more conventional or comprehensive for an English audience.

chunks.source_manual: <P062>Je ne trouve point cela bon, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Vous me disiez l'autre jour qu'on avoit donné aux differentes parties de la Lune des noms de Sçavans & d'Astronomes, & j'en estois fort contente. Puis que les Princes prennent pour eux la Terre, il est juste que les Sçavans se reservent le Ciel, & y dominent, mais ils n'en devroient point permettre l'entrée à d'autres. Souffrez, répondis-je, <UP></UP> qu'ils puissent, du moins en cas de besoin, engager aux Princes quelque Astre, ou quelque partie de la Lune. Quant aux taches du Soleil, ils n'en purent faire aucun usage. Il se trouva que ce n'estoient point des Planetes, mais des nuages, des fumées, des écumes, qui s'élèvent sur le Soleil. Elles sont tantost en grande quantité, tantost en petit nombre; tantost elles disparoissent toutes, quelquefois elles se mettent plusieurs ensemble, quelquefois elles se separent, quelquefois elles sont plus claires, quelquefois plus noires. Il y a des temps où l'on en voit beaucoup, il y en a d'autres, & mesme assez longs, où il n'en paroist aucune. Il semble que le Soleil soit une matiere liquide, quelques-uns disent de l'Or fondu, qui boüillonne incessamment <NCP></NCP>, & produit des impuretez, qui par la force de son mouvement sont rejettées sur sa surface. Elles s'y consument, & puis il s'en produit d'autres. Imaginez-vous quels Corps étrangers ce sont là. Il y en a tel qui est peut-estre aussi grand que la Terre. Jugez par là quelle est la quantité de cet Or fondu, ou l'étenduë de cette grande Mer de lumiere & de feu qu'on appelle le Soleil. D'autres disent que le Soleil paroît avec des Lunettes tout plein de Montagnes qui vomissent des flâmes, & que c'est comme un million de Monts Etna mis ensemble, mais on dit aussi que ces Montagnes sont une pure vision, causée par quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes. Aquoy se fiera-t-on, s'il faut se défier des Lunettes mesme, ausquelles nous devons la connoissance de tant de nouveaux objects. Enfin, quoy que ce puisse estre que le Soleil, il ne paroist nullement propre à estre habité. C'est pourtant dommage, l'habitation seroit belle. On seroit au centre de tout, on verroit toutes les Planetes tourner regulierement autour de soy, au lieu que nous voyons dans leur cours une infinité de bizareries, qui n'y paroissent que parce que nous ne sommes pas en le lieu propre pour en bien juger, c'est à dire, au centre de leur mouvement. Cela n'est-il pas pitoyable? Il n'y a qu'un lieu dans le Monde, d'où l'étude des Astres puisse estre extremément facile, & justement dans ce lieu-là, il n'y a personne. Vous n'y songez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Qui seroit dans le Soleil, verroit rien, ny Planetes, ny Etoiles Fixes. Le Soleil n'efface-t-il pas tout? Ce seroient ses Habitans qui seroient bien fondez à se croire seuls dans toute la Nature.</P062>
chunks.target_manual: <P047>I am not pleas'd with that at all, said the Marquiese: You told me the other Night, that the Philosophers and learned Men had given Names of Philosophers, Astronomers and Mathematicians to the several Countries of the Moon, and I was very well satisfy'd, and think it but just, that since the Kings and Princes possess the Earth, that they ought to suffer Philosophers and Astronomers to rule in the Moon and the Stars, without incroaching upon 'em. What, said I, Madam, Will not you allow Kings and Princes some Corner of the Moon, or some Star, to take their part in time of need? As to the Spots in the Sun, they can be of no manner of use to 'em; for it has been found, they are not Planets, but Clouds of Smoak and Vapours, and, as it were, a Scum arising from the Surface of the Sun; for sometimes they appear in great Quantities, sometimes in less, and at other times they dis-appear; sometimes they join in one, and other times they are dispers'd and dissipated; so that it shou'd seem, the Sun is a liquid Substance; some say, 'tis of melted Gold, <UP>which boils incessantly, and produces those Impurities</UP>; and by the force of its Motion, throws upon the Surface its Scum and Dross; and as those consume, new ones are produc'd. Pray, Madam, fansie to your self what strange Bodies these Spots of the Sun must be; there are some of 'em full as big as the Globe of the Earth; judge then what a great quantity there must be of this melted Gold, and of the Extent of this vast Ocean of Light and Fire, which we call the Sun. They say, the Sun appears, through Telescopes, to be full of great Mountains which vomit Flames, and that it is, as it were, a Million of Mount Aetna's, join'd together; but at the same time they acknowledge that these Mountains may be altogether visionary, and that they are nothing else but the Effects of the Glasses of the Telescopes. To whom shall we trust then, when these very Glasses, to which we owe so many new Discoveries, deceive us? In fine, Let the Sun be what it will, it does not at all seem proper to be inhabited; and yet 'tis pity, for the Situation wou'd be extreamly fine; its Inhabitants wou'd be plac'd in the Centre of the Universe, and wou'd see all the other Planets turn regularly round 'em, whereas we observe infinite Irregularities in their Course; and 'tis only because we are not in a proper Situation to consider 'em, as not being in the Centre of their Motion. Is it not hard, that there is but one place in the Universe, where the Study of the Stars wou'd be easie, and that that place alone shou'd be uninhabitable? You do not think, whilst you speak, said the Marquiese, were any living Creature in the Sun, he wou'd see neither Planets, nor fixed Stars; nor, indeed, any thing; the brightness of the Sun wou'd render all things else invisible; and if there were Inhabitants in the Sun, they wou'd be apt to believe themselves the only People in Nature.</P047>
