explanations: The translator added 'flying' to 'Birds' ('Oyseaux') to create a more dynamic image, possibly for stylistic enhancement or clarity.

The translator added 'as well to Mars' to specify the Marquise's concern immediately. The source makes a general statement about the necessity of moons at this point, while the target links this necessity directly to Mars, anticipating her subsequent complaint.

The translator significantly elaborated the French phrase 'if you involved yourself in Philosophy more than you do,' making it more formal and periphrastic, possibly to suit English literary conventions of the period or to soften the directness.
The translator inserted 'if you please' as a polite interjection common in English, softening the imperative mood of the suggestion.

The translator changed a declarative statement ('We would be very surprised') into a conversational prompt 'And tell me if it wou'd not be,' likely to enhance the dialogic style and engage the reader more directly.

The translator added 'in the World of' before 'Saturn.' This elaboration emphasizes Saturn as a distinct realm, aligning with the book's theme of exploring multiple worlds, a common practice in this translation style.

The source's 'from one end to the other of the Horizon' ('d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horison') is made more specific by the addition of 'opposite Points.' This addition clarifies the geometric configuration of the ring as spanning diametrically opposed parts of the horizon.
The translator added 'or great Circle' as an alternative or clarifying term for 'Ring' ('Anneau'), possibly to ensure reader comprehension or for stylistic variation.

The source states the moons 'had an equal motion' ('eussent un mouvement égal'). The translator added 'and turning one way,' specifying a characteristic of this motion (unidirectionality) that is not explicit in 'mouvement égal,' which could simply mean equal speed or regularity.

The translator added 'I spoke of' after 'the five little Moons.' This phrase acts as a cohesive device, explicitly reminding the reader that these moons were previously mentioned, an addition not present in the French text at this point.

The translator added 'or whirlings' as an explanatory gloss for the French term 'Tourbillon,' which refers to a vortex in Cartesian physics. This helps an English audience, potentially unfamiliar with the specific scientific term, understand its meaning.

The French phrase 'Quoy qu'il en soit' (Be that as it may / In any case) is rendered more specifically as 'whatever is the Cause.' This addition narrows the meaning by introducing the specific noun 'Cause,' an interpretation by the translator.

The source refers to 'l'Anneau' (the Ring). The translator has rendered this as 'this great Ring,' adding the adjective 'great.' While contextually appropriate, 'great' is an explicit addition by the translator not present in the French.
The translator added the introductory phrase ''Tis true,' a conversational marker not present in the source. This addition serves to make the dialogue flow more naturally in English.

The source's rhetorical exclamation 'mais quelle lumiere!' (but what light!) is interpreted and expanded by the translator into 'Sure a very feeble one.' This addition makes the implied meaning (that the light is feeble) explicit.

The source phrase 'expirer de chaud' (to die of heat) is rendered by the translator with the more graphic 'melt away with heat.' The phrase 'melt away' is an added descriptive element, replacing a more general term for dying with a specific vivid image of dissolution due to heat.

The source's 'en me parlant de Mercure' (by speaking to me of Mercury) is elaborated to 'with the descriptions you gave me of Mercury.' The addition 'with the descriptions you gave me' specifies the manner of speaking, adding a layer of detail.

The French indefinite pronoun 'on' (one/people) combined with 'dans Saturne' (in Saturn) is rendered as 'the Inhabitants of Saturn.' The phrase 'the Inhabitants of' is added to make the subject more specific and formal.

The French 'tout le monde' (everyone) combined with 'dans Mercure' (in Mercury) is translated as 'the Inhabitants of Mercury.' The phrase 'the Inhabitants of' is added to make the reference more formal and specific to the context of planetary populations.

The French 'on' (one/people) combined with 'dans Saturne' (in Saturn) is specified as 'the People of Saturn.' The phrase 'the People of' is added to replace the indefinite pronoun 'on' with a more concrete subject.

The target text adds 'so,' after 'in all Appearance' (translating 'selon toutes les apparences'). This 'so,' explicitly links the appearance of the Saturnians to the preceding discussion of wisdom ('If the People of Saturn...be not wise...they are at least in all Appearance so [wise]'). This connective 'so' is an addition by the translator.
The source's 'un jour' (a day) is expanded in the target to 'a whole days time'. The addition of 'whole' emphasizes the entirety of the day taken, a nuance not explicitly present in the source.

The target text 'a whole days time at least' includes 'at least' which is not in the source's 'un jour' (a day). This addition suggests the day taken is a minimum duration, an elaboration not present in the source.
The translator added the epithet 'the grave' to the figure of Cato. This descriptor is not present in the source text's 'Caton d'Utique.'
The translator replaced 'd'Utique' (of Utica), the original identifier for Cato, with 'the Censor.' This addition changes Cato's specific historical identity to Cato the Censor.

After describing Cato as 'too wild and youthful,' the translator added the phrase 'for their Conversation.' This addition provides a context for Cato's perceived unsuitability (i.e., for the Saturnians' company or discourse), a clarification not explicit in the source.

chunks.source_manual: <P082>Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle. Tous les Habitans de Mercure sont vifs, tous ceux de Saturne sont lens. Parmy nous les uns sont vifs, les autres lents; cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que nostre Terre étant justement au milieu des autres Mondes, nous participons des extremitez? Il n'y a point pour les hommes de Caractere fixe & déterminé; les uns sont faits comme les Habitans de Mercure, les autres comme ceux de Saturne, & nous sommes un mélange de toutes les especes qui se trouvent dans les autres Planetes. J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différens. A ce compte, il est assez commode d'estre icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.</P082> <P083>Du moins, reprit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, une commodité fort réelle qu'a nostre Monde par sa situation, c'est qu'il n'est ny si chaud que celuy de Mercure ou de Venus, ny si froid que celuy de Jupiter ou de Saturne. De plus, nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre où nous ne sentons l'excés ny du chaud ni du froid. En verité si un certain Philosophe rendoit grace à la Nature d'estre Homme, & non pas Beste, Grec, & non pas Barbare, moy je veux luy rendre grace d'estre sur la Planete la plus tempérée de l'Univers, & dans un des lieux les plus temperez de cette Planete. Si vous m'en croyez, Madame, répondis-je, vous luy rendrez grace d'estre jeune & non pas vieille; jeune & belle, & non pas jeune & laide; jeune & belle Françoise, & non pas jeune & <UP></UP> belle Italienne. Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de la situation de vostre Tourbillon, ou de la temperature de vostre Pays.</P083> <P084>Mon Dieu! repliqua-t-elle, laissez-moy avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout, jusque sur le Tourbillon où je suis placée. La mesure de bonheur qui nous a esté donnée, est assez petite; il n'en faut rien perdre, & il est bon d'avoir pour les choses les plus communes, & les moins considerables, un goust qui les mette à profit. Si on ne vouloit que des plaisirs vifs, on en auroit peu, on les attendroit long-temps, & on les payeroit bien. Vous me promettez donc, repliquay-je, que si on vous proposoit de ces plaisirs vifs, vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous? Ouy, répondit-elle, mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux. Du moins pour demain, répondis-je, j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas. J'ai des Etoiles Fixes qui passent tout ce que vous avez veu jusqu'icy.</P084>
chunks.target_manual: <P060>There is a thought come into my Head, said the Marquiese; all the Inhabitants of Mercury are very lively, and the Inhabitants of Saturn extremely dull: Now upon our Earth, we have a mixture of both, some are very airy, and some as insipid: Does not that proceed from our being situate in the middle, between these two Worlds, that we participate so of the Qualities of both these Extremes; and there is no fixt settled Character of Mankind; some resemble the Inhabitants of Mercury, others of Saturn; and we are a mixture of all the several kinds of People, that inhabit all the other Planets? I like that Idea well enough, said I, we are of such an extravagant Composition, that one wou'd really believe, that we were collected and drawn together from all the other Worlds. And at this rate, 'tis very convenient to live in ours, since here we see an abridgement of all that can be seen in the other Worlds. At least, said the Marquiese, Our World has one real advantage and conveniency, that it is neither so hot as Mercury or Venus, nor so cold as Iupiter and Saturn: And we have the good luck over and above, to be born in a Climate of this Earth, that has neither excess of heat nor cold. And if a certain Philosopher thank'd Nature for being a Man and not a Beast, a Grecian, and not a Barbarian; for my Part, I thank her, that I inhabit the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and the most temperate Climate of that Planet. If you will trust me, said I, Madam, you ought to thank her for being young, and not old, young and handsome, and not young and ugly, young, handsome, and a French Woman, and not a young and handsome Italian. You have abundance of other Reasons of Gratitude, than those of the Situation of your Tourbillion, or the temperate Qualities of your Country. Good God, said she, suffer me to be grateful for every thing; even to the very Tourbillion where I was born: The measure of the Happiness bestow'd upon us, is too little to lose any part of it; and it is good to have such a Sense and Taste of the commonest and most considerable things, as to turn all to our Advantage and Profit. If we shou'd look after no other Pleasure or Satisfaction, than this World afforded, we shou'd enjoy but very few, expect 'em long, and pay dear for 'em. If Philosophy be the Pleasure, you propose, said I, Madam, I have the Boldness to wish, that when you remember the Tourbillions, you wou'd be pleas'd to think of me. Yes, answer'd she, provided you take care your Philosophy furnishes me always with new Pleasures. At least, for to Morrow, answer'd I, I hope you shall not want; for I have the fixed Stars prepared for you, which surpass all you have hitherto heard.</P060>

chunks.source_manual: <P086><UP></UP>. La <IIM>Marquise</IIM> sentit une vraye impatience de sçavoir ce que les Etoiles Fixes deviendroient. Seront-elles habitées comme les Planetes, me dit-elle? Ne le seront-elles pas? Enfin qu'en ferons-nous? Vous le devineriez peut-estre, si vous en aviez bien envie, répondis-je. Les Etoiles Fixes ne sçauroient estre moins éloignées de la Terre que de quelques cinquante millions de lieuës, & si vous fâchiez un Astronome, il les mettroit encore plus loin. La distance du Soleil à la Planete la plus éloignée, n'est rien par rapport à la distance du Soleil ou de la Terre aux Etoiles Fixes, & on ne prend pas la peine de la compter. Leur lumiere, comme vous voyez, est assez vive & assez éclatante. Si elles la recevoient du Soleil, il faudroit qu'elles la receussent déja bien foible aprés un trajet de <IIM>cinquante millions de lieuës</IIM> <UP></UP>; il faudroit que par une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup, elles nous la renvoyassent à cette mesme distance. Il seroit impossible qu'une lumiere qui auroit essuyé une reflexion, & fait deux fois <IIM>cinquante millions de lieuës</IIM>, eust cette force et cette vivacité qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes. Les voila donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes, & toutes, en un mot, autant de Soleils.</P086> <P087>Ne me trompay-je point, s'écria la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener? M'allez-vous dire: Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils, nostre Soleil est le centre d'un Tourbillon qui tourne autour de luy, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe ne sera-t-elle pas aussi le centre d'un Tourbillon qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle? Nostre Soleil a des Planetes qu'il éclaire, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi qu'elle éclairera? Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis-je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toy qui l'as nommé. <UP></UP>.</P087> <P088>Mais, reprit-elle, voila l'Univers si grand que je m'y perds, je ne sçais plus où je suis, <RW>je ne suis plus rien</RW>. Quoy, tout sera divisé en Tourbillons jettez confusément les uns parmi les autres? Chaque Etoile sera le centre d'un Tourbillon peut-estre aussi grand que celuy où nous sommes? Tout cet espace immense qui comprend nostre Soleil & nos Planetes, ne sera qu'une petite parcelle de l'Univers? Autant d'espaces pareils que d'Etoiles Fixes? <UP></UP>. Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante. Et moy, répondis-je, cela me met à mon aise. Quand le Ciel n'estoit que cette voûte bleuë, où les Etoiles estoient cloüées, l'Univers me paroissoit petit & étroit, je m'y sentois comme oppressé; presentement qu'on a donné infiniment plus d'étenduë & de profondeur à cette voûte <UP></UP>, en la partageant en mille & mille <RW>Tourbillons</RW>, il me semble que je respire avec plus de liberté, & que je suis dans un plus grand air, & asseurement l'Univers a toute une autre magnificence. La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle. Rien n'est si beau à se representer que ce nombre prodigieux de Tourbillons, dont le milieu est occupé par un Soleil qui fait tourner des Planetes autour de luy. Les Habitans d'une Planete d'un de ces Tourbillons infinis voyent de tous costez les centres lumineux des Tourbuillons dont ils sont environnez, mais ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes qui n'ayant qu'une lumiere foible, empruntée de leur Soleil, ne la poussent point au delà de leur Monde.<UP></UP>.</P088> <P089>Vous m'offrez, dit-elle, une espece de Perspective si longue, que la veuë n'en peut attraper le bout. Je voy clairement les Habitans de la Terre, ensuite vous me faites voir ceux de la Lune & des autres Planetes de nostre Tourbillon assez clairement à la verité, mais moins que ceux de la Terre; apres eux viennent les Habitans des Planetes des autres Tourbillons. Je vous avoüe qu'ils sont tout-à-fait dans l'enfoncement, & que quelque effort que je fasse pour les voir, je ne les apperçois presque point. Et en effet ne sont-ils pas presque aneantis par l'expression dont vous estes obligé de vous servir en parlant d'eux? Il faut que vous les appeliez, les Habitans d'une des Planetes, de l'un de ces Tourbillons infinis? <IIM>Nous mesmes, à qui la mesme expression convient, avoüez que vous ne sçauriez presque plus nous déméler au milieu de tant de Mondes</IIM>. Pour moy, je commence à voir la Terre si effroyablement petite, que je ne croy pas avoir desormais d'empressement pour aucune chose. <IIM>Asseurément, si on a tant d'ardeur de s'agrandir, si on fait desseins sur desseins, si on se donne tant de peine, c'est que l'on ne connoist pas les Tourbillons</IIM>. <UP></UP>. Je pretends bien que ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres, & quand on me reprochera mon indolence, je répondray: Ah! si vous sçaviez ce que c'est que les Etoiles Fixes! Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas sceu, repliquay-je, car un certain Auteur qui tient que la Lune est habitée, dit fort serieusement qu'il n'estoit pas possible qu'Aristote ne fust dans une opinion si raisonnable (comment une verité eust-elle échappé à Aristote?) <UP></UP> mais qu'il n'en voulut jamais rien dire, de peur de déplaire, à Alexandre, qui eust esté au despoir de voir un Monde qu'il n'eust pas pû conquerir. A plus forte raison luy eust-on fait mystere des Tourbillons, des Etoiles Fixes, quand on les eust connus en ce temps-là; c'eust esté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler. Pour moy qui les connois, je suis bien fâché de ne pouvoir tirer d'utilité de la connoissance que j'en ay. Ils ne guerissent tout au plus, selon vostre raisonnement, que de l'ambition & de l'inquietude, & je n'ay point ces maladies-là. Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau, voila mon mal, & je ne croy pas que les Tourbillons y puissent rien. Les autres Mondes vous rendent celuy-cy petit, mais ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux, ou une belle bouche, cela vaut toûjours son prix en dépit de tous les Mondes possibles.</P089>
chunks.target_manual: <P062><UP>MY</UP> Lady Marquiese was very impatient to know what shou'd become of the fix'd Stars. Can they be inhabited as the Planets are, said she to me? or are they not inhabited? what shall we make of 'em? If you wou'd take the Pains, you cou'd not fail to guess, said I, Madam, the fixt Stars cannot be less distant from the Earth, than <IIM>fifty Millions of Leagues</IIM>; nay, some Astronomers make the distance yet greater; that between the Sun and the remotest Planet is nothing if compared to the distance between the Sun or Earth, and the fix'd Stars; we do not trouble our selves to number 'em, their Lustre as you see is both clear and bright. If the fix'd Stars, receive their Light from the Sun, it must certainly be very weak and faint before it comes to 'em, having passed through a <IIM>hundred and fifty Millions of Miles</IIM> of the Celestial Substance, I spoke of before: Then consider, the fix'd Stars are oblig'd, to reflect this borrow'd Light upon us at the same distance, which Is every fixt Star the Center of a Tourbillion; and it may be full as big as our Sun? Is it possible, that all this Immense space, wherein our Sun and Planets have their Revolution, is nothing but an inconsiderable part of the Universe? And that every fix'd Star must comprehend and govern an equal space with our Sun? This confounds, afflicts, and frightens me. And for my part, said I, it pleases and rejoices me; when I believ'd the Universe to be nothing, but this great Azure Vault of the Heavens, wherein the Stars were placed, as it were so many golden Nails or Studs, the Universe seem'd to me too little and strait; I fansied my self to be confin'd and oppress'd: But now when I am perswaded, that this Azure Vault has a greater depth and a vaster Extent, and that 'tis divided into a thousand and a thousand different Tourbillions or Whirlings, I imagine I am at more Liberty, and breath a freer Air; and the Universe appears to me to be infinitely more Magnificent. Nature has spared nothing in her Production, and hath profusely bestow'd her Treasures upon a glorious Work worthy of her: You can represent nothing so august to your self, as this prodigious Number of Tourbillions, whose Center is possess'd by a Sun, that makes the Planets turn round him. The Inhabitants of the Planets of any of these infinite Tourbillions, see from all sides the enlightned Center of the Tourbillion with which they are inviron'd; but cannot discover the Planets of another, who enjoy but a faint Light, borrow'd from their own Sun, which it does not dart further than its own Sphere or Activity. You show me, said the Marquiese, so vast a Prospect, that my sight cannot reach to the end of it: I see clearly the Inhabitants of our World; and you have plainly presented to my Reason the Inhabitants of the Moon, and other Planets of our Tourbillion or Whirling: After this you tell me of the Inhabitants of the Planets of all the other Tourbillions. I confess, they seem to me to be sunk into so boundless a depth, that whatever force I put upon my Fancy, I cannot comprehend 'em; and indeed you have annihilated 'em by the Expressions you made use of in speaking of 'em and their Inhabitants. You must certainly call 'em the Inhabitants of one of the Planets, of one of these infinite Tourbillions; and what shall become of us in the middle of so many Worlds; since the Title you give to the rest agrees to this of ours? And for my Part, I see the Earth so dreadfully little, that hereafter I shall scorn to be concern'd for any part of it. <UP>And I admire why Mankind are so very fond of Power </UP>, so earnest after Grandure, laying design upon design, circumventing, betraying, flattering, and poorly lying, and are at all this mighty Pains to grasp a part of a World they neither know nor understand, nor any thing of these mighty Tourbillions: For me, I'll lazily contemn it, and my carelesness shall have this Advantage by my Knowledge, that when any Body shall reproach me with my Poverty, I will with vanity reply, Oh! you do not know what the fix'd Stars are. I do believe, said I, Madam, that Alexander the Great himself did not know: For a certain Author who holds that the Moon is inhabited, says very gravely, that it was impossible, but Aristotle must be of so reasonable an Opinion (for how cou'd such a truth escape so <UP>great a Man</UP> as Aristotle?) but that he wou'd never say any thing of it for fear of displeasing Alexander; for had he known there had been a World which he cou'd not have conquer'd, it wou'd have reduc'd him to certain Despair. There was yet more Reason to conceal the Tourbillions of the fix'd Stars from him; if they had been known in those Days, he wou'd have made his Court very ill to that great Prince, who shou'd but have mention'd 'em. As for me who know 'em, I am very sorry I can draw no advantage from that Knowledge, which can cure nothing but Ambition and Disquiet, and none of these Diseases trouble me. I confess a kind of Weakness in Love, a kind of frailty for what is delicate and handsom, this is my Distemper, wherein the Tourbillions are not concern'd at all. The infinite Multitude of other Worlds may render this little in your Esteem, but they do not spoil fine Eyes, a pretty Mouth, or make the Charms of Wit ever the less: These will still have their true Value, still bear a price in spight of all the Worlds in the Universe.</P062>

The translator added the discourse marker 'Then consider,' to guide the reader through the logical steps of the philosopher's argument, improving the flow of the text in English.

The translator converted 'cinquante millions de lieuës' (fifty million leagues) to 'a hundred and fifty Millions of Miles,' including the unit 'Miles,' to make the distance more comprehensible for an English audience accustomed to imperial units.

The translator added 'and govern' to the description of a fixed star's role within the target sentence 'And that every fixt Star must comprehend and govern an equal space with our Sun?', attributing a more active agency (governing its space) to the star than the source explicitly states in the Marquise's speculation about stars being centers of tourbillons.

The translator elaborated on 'où les Etoiles estoient cloüées' (where the stars were nailed) with the more vivid and descriptive phrase 'as it were so many golden Nails or Studs,' enhancing the imagery.

The translator added 'different' to 'Tourbillions' (in the phrase 'a thousand and a thousand different Tourbillions or Whirlings'), emphasizing the variety among the cosmic systems, a nuance not explicit in the source.

The translator provided 'or Whirlings' as an English equivalent or clarification for the French term 'Tourbillions,' aiding comprehension for an audience potentially unfamiliar with Cartesian physics terminology.
The translator added 'upon a glorious Work' to specify that Nature's profusion of treasures was bestowed upon the Universe, described as a 'glorious Work,' thereby emphasizing its magnificence.

The translator replaced/elaborated 'leur Monde' (their World) with the more conceptual 'its own Sphere or Activity,' possibly to lend a more scientific or defined scope to the limit of a sun's light from a distant planetary system.

The translator clarified 'vous me faites voir ... assez clairement' (you make me see ... clearly enough) as 'plainly presented to my Reason,' specifying that the Marquise's understanding is intellectual rather than visual.

The translator added the explicit comparison 'and it may be full as big as our Sun?' to the Marquise's rhetorical questions about fixed stars. While the source ('Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils') implies similarity, this addition makes the size comparison direct and emphatic.

The translator expanded 'si on a tant d'ardeur de s'agrandir' (if one has so much desire to aggrandize oneself) into a broader social critique: 'And I admire why Mankind are so very fond of Power, so earnest after Grandure,' making the observation more specific and directed at 'Mankind'.

The translator inserted a list of specific negative actions ('circumventing, betraying, flattering, and poorly lying,') where the source text was more general ('si on fait desseins sur desseins, si on se donne tant de peine' - if one makes plans upon plans, if one takes so much trouble), thus adding a strong moralizing tone.

The translator elaborated on the consequences of ignorance about tourbillons ('c'est que l'on ne connoist pas les Tourbillons') by specifying that people strive 'to grasp a part of a World they neither know nor understand, nor any thing of these mighty Tourbillions,' highlighting the futility and ignorance of such pursuits.

The translator changed the object of reproach from 'mon indolence' (my indolence) in the source to 'my Poverty,' shifting the social context of the Marquise's detachment to encompass material circumstances.
The translator added 'with vanity' to describe the Marquise's manner of replying ('je répondray'), providing an explicit indication of her emotional state or attitude not present in the source.
The translator added 'Madam' again, maintaining the formal and polite tone of the dialogue in English.
The translator expanded 'Alexandre' to 'Alexander the Great himself,' using the common English epithet 'the Great' and adding 'himself' for emphasis.
The translator elaborated on 'Aristote?' within the parenthetical question by adding 'so great a Man as,' emphasizing Aristotle's esteemed reputation explicitly.
The translator added 'to that great Prince,' when referring to Alexander, making the reference more explicit and formal than the source's pronoun 'luy' (him).
The translator introduced the philosopher's admission with 'I confess,' making the statement more personal and direct than the source's descriptive opening.

The translator expanded 'pour ce qui est beau' (for what is beautiful) to the more elaborate and romanticized 'in Love, a kind of frailty for what is delicate and handsom,' adding specific connotations of amorous sentiment and refined taste.
The translator amplified 'Les autres Mondes' (The other Worlds) to 'The infinite Multitude of other Worlds,' stressing the immense number and scale of these other systems.
The translator added 'in your Esteem,' to 'vous rendent celuy-cy petit' (make this one small), clarifying that the perceived smallness of Earth is a subjective valuation.

The translator introduced 'or make the Charms of Wit ever the less,' adding intellectual attractiveness ('Charms of Wit') to the list of human attributes (eyes, mouth) that retain their value despite the universe's vastness. This element is not mentioned in the source.

chunks.source_manual: <P090>C'est une étrange chose que l'Amour, répondit-elle en riant; il se sauve de tout, & il n'y a point de Systême qui luy puisse faire de mal. Mais aussi parlez-moy franchement, vostre Systême est-il bien vray? Ne me déguisez rien, je vous garderay le secret. Il me semble qu'il n'est appuyé que sur une petite convenance bien legere. Une Etoile Fixe & lumineuse d'elle-mesme comme le Soleil, par consequent il faut qu'elle soit comme le Soleil, le centre & l'ame d'un Monde, & qu'elle ait ses Planetes qui tournent autour d'elle. Cela est-il d'une necessité bien absoluë? Ecoutez, Madame, répondis-je, puis que nous sommes en humeur de mêler toûjours des folies de galanterie à nos Discours les plus serieux, les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour. Vous ne sçauriez accorder si peu de chose à un Amant, que bien-tost aprés il ne faille luy en accorder davantage, & puis encore davantage, & à la fin cela va loin. De mesme accordez à un Mathematicien le moindre principe, il va vous en tirer une consequence, qu'il faudra que vous luy accordiez aussi, & de cette consequence encore une autre, & malgré vous-mesme il vous mene si loin, qu'à peine le pouvez-vous croire. Ces deux sortes de Gens-là prennent toûjours plus qu'on ne leur donne. Vous convenez que quand deux choses sont semblables en tout ce qui me paroist, je les puis croire aussi semblables en ce qui ne me paroist point, s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empesche. De là j'ay tiré que la Lune estoit habitée, parce qu'elle ressemble à la Terre, les autres Planetes, parce qu'elles ressemblent à la Lune. Je trouve que les Etoiles Fixes ressemblent à nostre Soleil, je leur attribuë tout ce qu'il a. Vous estes engagée trop avant pour pouvoir reculer, il faut franchir le pas de bonne grace. Mais, dit-elle, sur le pied de cette ressemblance que vous mettez entre les Etoiles Fixes & nostre Soleil, il faut que les Gens d'un autre grand Tourbillon ne le voyent que comme une petite Etoile Fixe, qui se montre à eux seulement pendant leurs nuits.</P090> <P091>Cela est hors de doute, répondis-je. Nostre Soleil est si proche de nous en comparaison des Soleils des autres Tourbillons, que sa lumiere doit avoir infiniment plus de force sur nos yeux que la leur. Nous ne voyons donc que luy quand nous le voyons, & il efface tout; mais dans un autre grand Tourbillon c'est un autre Soleil qui y domine, & il efface à son tour le nostre, qui n'y paroist que pendant les nuits avec le reste des autres Soleils étrangers, c'est à dire, des Etoiles Fixes. On l'attache avec elles à cette grande voûte du Ciel, & il y fait partie de quelque Ourse, ou de quelque Taureau. Pour les Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, <NCP>nostre Terre, par exemple</NCP>, comme on ne les voit point de si loin, on n'y songe seulement pas. Ainsi tous les Soleils, sont Soleils de jour pour le Tourbillon où ils sont placez, & Soleils de nuit pour tous les autres Tourbillons. Dans leur Monde, ils sont les uniques de leur espece, par tout ailleurs ils ne servent qu'à faire nombre. Ne faut-il pas pourtant, reprit-elle, que les Mondes, malgré cette égalité different en mille choses, car un fond de ressemblance ne laisse de porter des differences infinies?</P091>
chunks.target_manual: <P063>It is a strange thing, said the Marquiese laughing, that Love saves himself from all Dangers, and there is no Systeme or Opinion can hurt him: But tell me frankly, are your Systemes certainly true? Do not dissemble, for I promise to keep it secret: I fansie 'tis founded upon a very small bottom, a fix'd Star enlightned of it self, as the Sun is, and therefore it must be a Sun, the Soul and Center of the World having Planets turning round it as that also has. Is this absolutely necessary, says she? I fear, Madam, said I: Since we are always in the humour of mixing some little Gallantries with our most serious Discourses, give me leave to tell you, that Mathematical reasoning is in some things near a-kin to Love; and you cannot allow the smallest Favour to a Lover, but he will soon perswade you to yield another, and after that a little more, and in the end prevails entirely; so if you grant the least Principle to a Mathematician, he will instantly draw a consequence from it, which you must yield also, and from that another, and then a third, and maugre all your Resistance, in a short time, he will lead you so far, that you cannot retreat. These two sorts of Men, The Lover and Philosopher always take more than is given 'em. You must acknowledge that when I see two Objects alike in every thing that I do see, I have Reason to believe them to be also alike in what I see not; for where is the hindrance or difficulty? From thence I have argu'd that the Moon is inhabited because it is like the Earth; that the other Planets are inhabited because they are like the Moon. I find that the fix'd Stars are like our Sun as to what I see; and therefore, I conclude they are Suns, and have Planets turning round about 'em; and every thing else we attribute to our Suns. Now, Madam, you are too far engag'd to retire; and therefore you must generously yield. By this rule of resemblance, said she, which you make betwixt our Sun and the fix'd Stars, the Inhabitants of another Tourbillion, must only see our Sun as a small fix'd Star, which only appears to them, during their Night. Without doubt, said I, Madam, our Sun is so near us, in respect of the Suns of the other Tourbillions, that his Light must have infinitely greater force upon our Sight than the Light of the other Suns; when we see our Sun, we see nothing else, his brightness makes all other things disappear: In another great Tourbillion, where another Sun governs, he in his turn removes and darkens our Sun, which does not appear, but in the Night as a fix'd Star amongst the other strange Suns (that is) fix'd Stars, and our Sun appears to the Inhabitants of that Tourbillion in the great Vault of the Heavens, as a Star of some Constellation, such as the Bear or the Bull: As to the Planets which turn round about him <NCP>(as our Earth for example)</NCP> since they cannot see it at so great a distance, they do not so much as think of it, so that all these Suns are Suns by day for the Tourbillion which they govern, and fix'd Stars by Night; for all the other, every one of them is the only one of his kind in his own World; but serve only to make up the Number of fix'd Stars for all the other Worlds. Notwithstanding, said she, of this Equality of Resemblance of the Worlds, yet I cannot believe, but they differ in a thousand things, for likeness upon the main does not hinder infinite little differences.</P063>

chunks.source_manual: <P092>Assurément, repris-je, mais la difficulté est de deviner. Que sçay-je? Un Tourbillon a plus de Planetes qui tournent autour de son Soleil, un autre en a moins. Dans l'un il y a des Planetes subalternes, qui tournent autour des Planetes plus grandes; dans l'autre il n'y en a point. Icy elles sont toutes ramassées autour de leur Soleil <UP></UP>, & font comme un petit peloton, au-delà duquel s'étend un grand espace vuide, qui va jusqu'aux Tourbillons voisins; ailleurs elles prennent leur cours vers les extremitez du Tourbillon & laissent le milieu vuide. Je ne doute pas mesme qu'il ne puisse y avoir quelques Tourbillons deserts, & sans Planetes, d'autres dont le Soleil, n'estant pas justement au centre, ait un veritable mouvement, & emporte ses Planetes avec soy; d'autres dont les Planetes s'élèvent ou s'abaissent à l'égard de leur Soleil par le changement de l'équilibre qui les tient suspenduës. Enfin, que voudriez-vous? En voila bien assez pour un homme qui n'est jamais sorty de son Tourbillon.</P092>
chunks.target_manual: <P064>Most certainly, said I; but the difficulty will be, to find out those Differences. What do I know but in one Tourbillion, there are more Planets turning round it than in another? In one there are Inferior Planets turning round the greater, in another there are none at all: In one Tourbillion the Planets are gather'd together, as it were a little Party, round their Sun, and beyond them a vast Vacuity, extending to the next Tourbillion; in another, the Planets take their Course towards the Extremity of their Tourbillion, and leave a Void in the middle, and I do not doubt but there are Tourbillions destitute of Planets; and others, where their Sun is not plac'd in the middle, and yet has a free Motion, and carries his Planets round with him; others, where the Planets rise and fall in respect of their Sun, according to the Changes of the Counterpoise which balances 'em. What wou'd you have, Madam? Have not I said enough for a Man that was never out of his own Tourbillion?</P064>

explanations: The French phrase 'est de deviner' (is to guess/surmise) leaves the object of the verb 'deviner' implicit. The translator adds 'to find out those Differences' to make the philosopher's intended speculation more concrete and to explicitly name the subject of this guesswork – the variations among Tourbillons which are subsequently listed. This addition enhances clarity and foreshadows the upcoming points for the reader.

The French source uses 'Icy' (Here, or In this case) to introduce the first hypothetical arrangement of planets. The translator replaces this with the more explicit phrase 'In one Tourbillion', thereby specifying that 'Icy' refers to a particular configuration within a Tourbillion system. This provides clearer context for the English reader, especially in contrast to 'ailleurs' (elsewhere) which is translated as 'in another'.

The translator adds 'Madam' as a direct term of address to the Marquise, which is not present in the French source text. This addition makes the dialogue conform more closely to English conversational conventions of the period, reinforces the politeness of the exchange, and explicitly identifies the addressee for the reader.

chunks.source_manual: <P093>Ce n'en est guere, répondit-elle, pour la quantité des Mondes. Ce que vous dites ne suffit que pour cinq ou six, & j'en voy d'icy des milliers?</P093>
chunks.target_manual: <P065>No, said she, not for the quantity of Worlds which you say there is: What you have describ'd will suffice but for five or six, and I see thousands.</P065>
source_segments: pour la quantité des Mondes
Ce que vous dites
target_segments: not for the quantity of Worlds which you say there is:
explanations: The translator added the clause 'which you say there is' to the corresponding phrase in the target text. This addition explicitly links the Marquise's statement to the philosopher's preceding discourse, clarifying that she is referring to the quantity of worlds as he has presented them, thus enhancing the context for the reader.

The translator rendered 'Ce que vous dites' (literally 'what you say') as 'What you have describ'd'. The use of the verb 'describ'd' is an elaboration not directly present in the source verb 'dites'. This specification clarifies that the philosopher's prior statements were detailed descriptions rather than general remarks, adding a layer of detail and precision for the reader.

chunks.source_manual: <P094>Que serait-ce donc, repris-je, si je vous disois qu'il y a bien d'autres Etoiles Fixes, que celles que vous voyez; qu'avec des Lunettes on en découvre un nombre infiny qui ne se montrent point aux yeux, & que dans une seule Constellation, où l'on en comptoit peut-estre douze ou quinze <RW></RW>, il s'en trouve autant que l'on en voyoit <UP></UP> auparavant dans tout le Ciel?</P094>
chunks.target_manual: <P066>What wou'd you say, Madam, said I, if I shou'd tell you that there are infinitely more fixed Stars than those you see, that by the help of Telescopes an uncountable number are discover'd, which we cannot see with our Eyes alone; and that in one Constellation, where we counted but twelve or fifteen <RW>fixed Stars </RW>, there have been discover'd more than we see with our Eyes in the whole Heavens?</P066>
source_segments: Que serait-ce donc, repris-je,
qui ne se montrent point aux yeux
où l'on en comptoit peut-estre douze ou quinze
que l'on en voyoit auparavant
explanations: The translator added 'Madam' as a polite form of address common in English dialogues of the period. This addition enhances the naturalness of the conversation for the target audience, as the French 'repris-je' (I replied/resumed) does not explicitly contain this vocative.

The translator added 'alone' to 'with our Eyes' (which translates 'aux yeux') to explicitly clarify that the stars in question are invisible to the *unaided* eye. This elaboration provides greater precision than the French 'aux yeux' (to the eyes/with the eyes).

The source text uses the pronoun 'en' ('of them') to refer to 'Etoiles Fixes' (Fixed Stars) mentioned earlier: '...où l'on en comptoit peut-estre douze ou quinze' (where one counted perhaps twelve or fifteen of them). The translator chose to explicitly restate 'fixed Stars' after 'twelve or fifteen' for enhanced clarity, avoiding reliance on the pronominal reference which might be less direct for an English reader.

The source phrase 'que l'on en voyoit auparavant' (that one previously saw of them) does not specify the method of prior observation. The translator added 'with our Eyes' to make it explicit that the comparison is to what was visible to the naked eye, thereby clarifying the baseline for comparison with telescope discoveries.

chunks.source_manual: <P095>Je vous demande grace, s'écria-t-elle, je me rends, vous m'accablez de Mondes & de Tourbillons. Je sçay bien, ajoûtay-je, ce que je vous garde ancore. Vous voyez cette blancheur qu'on appelle la Voye de Lait. Vous figureriez-vous bien ce que c'est? Une infinité de petites Etoiles invisibles aux yeux à cause de leur petitesse, & semées si prés les unes des autres qu'elles paroissent former une blancheur continuë. Je voudrois que vous vissiez avec des Lunettes cette Fourmilliere d'Astres, & cette graine de Mondes (si ces expressions sont permises.) Ils ressemblent en quelque sorte aux Isles Maldives, à ces douze mille petites Isles ou Bancs de Sable, separez seulement par des Canaux de Mer, que l'on sauteroit presque comme des Fossez. Ainsi les petits Tourbillons de la Voye de Lait sont si serrez, qu'il me semble que d'un Monde à l'autre on pourroit se parler, ou mesme se donner la main. Du moins je croy que les Oyseaux d'un Monde passent aisément dans un autre, & que l'on y peut dresser des Pigeons à porter des Lettres comme on fait icy dans le Levant. Ces petits Mondes sortent apparemment de la regle generale, par laquelle un Soleil dans son Tourbillon efface dés qu'il paroist tous les Soleils étrangers. Si vous estes dans un des petits Tourbillons de la Voye de Lait, vostre Soleil n'est presque pas plus proche de vous, & par consequent n'a pas sensiblement plus de force sur vos yeux, que cent mille autres Soleils des Tourbillons voisins. Vous voyez donc vostre Ciel briller d'un nombre infiny de feux, qui sont fort proches les uns des autres, & peu éloignez de vous. Lors que vous perdez de veuë vostre Soleil particulier, il vous en reste encore assez, & vostre nuit n'est pas moins éclairée que le jour, du moins la diference ne peut pas estre sensible, & pour parler plus juste, vous n'avez jamais de nuit. Ils seroient bien étonnez, les Gens de ces Mondes-là, accoûtumez comme ils sont à une clarté perpetuelle, si on leur disoit qu'il y a des malheureux qui ont de veritables nuits, qui tombent dans des tenebres tres-profondes, & qui quand ils joüissent de la lumiere, ne voyent mesme qu'un seul Soleil. Ils nous regarderoient comme des Estres disgraciez de la Nature, & fremiroient de l'horreur de nostre condition.</P095>
chunks.target_manual: <P067>I ask your Pardon, said she; I yield and confess, you have over-charg'd me with Worlds and Tourbillions. Madam, said I, I have still a Reserve for you: You see that Whiteness in the Hemisphere, call'd The Milky Way; Can you imagine what it is? 'Tis nothing but an Infinity of little fixed Stars, which cannot be seen by our Eyes, because they are so very small, and are plac'd so near to one another, that they appear to be but one continued Whiteness: I wish you cou'd see this Anthill or Stars, and these Seeds of Worlds; they look like the Maldevia- Islands, or those twelve thousand little Isles, or Banks of Sand, separate only by small Canals of the Sea, which one may over-leap with as much Ease as a Ditch. So that these little Tourbillions of the Milky Way, being so near one to another, may converse and shake hands with those of their Neighbouring World; at least, the Birds of one World may fly into another; and they may teach Pidgeons to carry Letters, as they do in the Levant. By which, the Sun, in his own Tourbillion, as soon as he begins to spread his Light, he faceth that of all other Stranger-Suns; for if you were in one of these little Tourbillions of the Milky Way, your Sun wou'd not be so near to you; and by consequence, wou'd have but little more power, force, or influence upon your Eyes, than a hundred thousand other Suns of the neighbouring Tourbillions; you wou'd then see your Heaven shining with an infinite number of Fires, very near to one another, and not far distant from you; and tho' you shou'd lose the sight of your own Sun, you wou'd still have Light enough, and your Nights wou'd be no less bright than your Days; at least, you wou'd not be sensible of the difference; or, to speak more properly, you wou'd have no Night at all: The Inhabitants of this World, accustom'd to perpetual Day, wou'd be strangely surpriz'd if one shou'd tell 'em, that there are several People in the Universe, who are under the Tribulation of dismal, real Nights, and who fall into long and profound Darknesses, and who, when the Light returns, behold one and the same Sun: They wou'd look upon such People as the Out-casts of Nature, and the very Thoughts of our sad Condition wou'd sieze them with Horrour.</P067>

explanations: The French 'je me rends' means 'I yield' or 'I surrender.' The translator added 'and confess' to make the Marquise's concession more explicit and emphatic, adding a verbal admission to the act of yielding.

The French source does not include a direct term of address here. The translator added 'Madam' as a conventional and polite form of address appropriate for the context of a philosopher speaking to a Marquise in English of that period, normalizing the dialogue's formality.

The French 'cette blancheur' (this whiteness) refers to the Milky Way. The translator added 'in the Hemisphere' to provide specific spatial context, clarifying that this 'whiteness' is a celestial phenomenon observed in the sky, aiding reader comprehension.

The French 'Une infinité de petites Etoiles' means 'an infinity of little stars.' The translator added 'fixed' to specify them as 'fixed Stars,' an astronomical distinction of the era differentiating them from planets ('wandering stars'). This addition provides scientific clarity.

The French 'cette Fourmilliere d'Astres' (this anthill of stars) is a metaphor. The translator added 'or Stars' as an appositive, explicitly clarifying the metaphor by stating that 'Anthill' refers to a dense collection of stars.

The French 'd'un Monde à l'autre' (from one World to another) describes the interaction. The English translation elaborates this by adding 'with those of their Neighbouring World' after 'may converse and shake hands' (which translates 'on pourroit se parler, ou mesme se donner la main'). This addition specifies the interactants more concretely ('those of') and characterizes the other world as 'Neighbouring,' providing greater detail.

The French 'dés qu'il paroist' means 'as soon as it appears.' The translator elaborated this to 'as soon as he begins to spread his Light,' creating a more active and descriptive image of the sun's appearance and the start of its influence.

The French 'plus de force' (more strength/power) is rendered as 'little more power, force, or influence.' The additions 'power,' and 'or influence' create a triplet, a rhetorical device used to amplify the meaning of 'force' and convey its full semantic range with emphasis.

The French 'des malheureux' means 'unfortunate ones/people.' The translator added 'in the Universe' to the phrase 'several People,' specifying the broader cosmic setting of these individuals, which aligns with the book's themes.

The French 'qui ont de veritables nuits' (who have real nights) is a relatively neutral statement. The translator added 'who are under the Tribulation of dismal' to significantly intensify the negative perception of having nights, framing it as a state of suffering and adding strong emotional judgment not explicit in the source.

The French 'des tenebres tres-profondes' means 'very profound darknesses.' The translator added 'long and,' introducing the aspect of duration to the description of these darknesses, an element not explicitly present in the source.

The French 'fremiroient de l'horreur de nostre condition' means '[they] would shudder with the horror of our condition.' The translator added 'the very Thoughts of,' specifying that it is the contemplation or thought of the condition, rather than the condition itself, that elicits horror, introducing a psychological nuance.

The French 'nostre condition' (our condition) is a neutral term. The translator added the adjective 'sad' to 'our Condition,' explicitly characterizing this state as unfortunate or pitiable from the perspective of beings accustomed to perpetual daylight.

chunks.source_manual: <P096>Je ne vous demande pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, s'il y a des Lunes dans les Mondes de la Voye de Lait; je voy bien qu'elles n'y seroient de nul usage aux Planetes principales qui n'ont point de nuit, & qui d'ailleurs marchent dans des espaces trop étroits pour s'embarrasser de cet attirail de Planetes subalternes. Mais sçavez-vous bien qu'à force de me multiplier les Mondes si liberalement, vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté? Les Tourbillons dont nous voyons les Soleils, touchent le Tourbillon où nous sommes. Les Tourbillons sont ronds, n'est-il pas vray? Et comment tant de Boules en peuvent-elles toucher une seule? Je veux m'imaginer cela, & je sens bien que je ne le puis.</P096>
chunks.target_manual: <P068>I do not ask you, said the Marquiese, whether there be any Moons in the World of the Milky Way; I see very well, that they wou'd be of no use to these Planets that have no Night; and who besides, move in too little Room to be troubled with an Equipage of inferior Planets. But do you know that by your multiplying upon me such a multitude of Worlds, you have started a great Difficulty to my Fancy, which, I doubt, you will hardly satisfy: The Tourbillions, whose Suns we see touch the Tourbillions where we are, and all the Tourbillions are round, how is it possible that so many different Globes can touch one single one? This I wou'd willingly understand, but find I cannot.</P068>
source_segments: qu'à force de me multiplier les Mondes si liberalement
vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté?
vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté?
Et comment tant de Boules en peuvent-elles toucher une seule?
target_segments: , which, I doubt, you will hardly satisfy:
explanations: The translator adds "such a multitude of" to "Worlds" (which translates "les Mondes" from the source clause "qu'à force de me multiplier les Mondes si liberalement"). This elaborates on the quantity implied by "si liberalement" (so liberally), making the large number of worlds more explicit.

"to my Fancy" is added to "a great Difficulty" (which translates "une veritable difficulté" from the source clause "vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté?"). This clarifies that the difficulty is in the Marquise's imagination or understanding, a detail not present in the source.

This clause is entirely new. After the Marquise states that a difficulty has arisen (corresponding to the source clause "vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté?"), the target text adds her explicit expression of doubt ("I doubt") and a challenge to the philosopher ("you will hardly satisfy:"), which enhances her characterization and the dialogue's dramatic tension.

The translator adds the adjective "different" to "Globes" (which translates "Boules" from the source question "Et comment tant de Boules en peuvent-elles toucher une seule?"). This specifies that the globes being discussed are distinct entities, a clarification absent in the source's phrase "tant de Boules" (so many Spheres/Balls).

chunks.source_manual: <P097>Il y a beaucoup d'esprit, répondis-je, à avoir cette difficulté-là, & mesme à ne la pouvoir résoudre; car elle est tres-bonne en soy, & de la maniere dont vous la concevez, elle est sans réponse, & c'est avoir bien peu d'esprit que de trouver des réponses à ce qui n'en a point. Si nostre Tourbillon estoit de la figure d'un Dé, il auroit six faces plates, & seroit bien éloigné d'estre rond, mais sur chacune de ces faces on y pourroit mettre un Tourbillon de la mesme figure. Si au lieu de six faces plates, il en avoit vingt, cinquante, mille, il y auroit jusqu'à mille Tourbillons qui pourroient poser sur luy, chacun sur une face, & vous concevez bien que plus un corps a de faces plates qui le terminent au dehors, plus il <IIM>approche d'estre rond</IIM>, en sorte qu'un Diamant taillé à facetes de tous costez, si les facetes estoient fort petites, seroit quasi aussi rond qu'une Perle de mesme grandeur. Les Tourbillons ne sont ronds que de cette maniere-là. Ils ont une infinité de faces en dehors, chacune des quelles porte un autre Tourbillon. Ces faces sont fort inégales; icy elles sont plus grandes, là plus petites. Les plus petites de nostre Tourbillon, par exemple, répondent à la Voye de Lait, & soutiennent tous ces petits Mondes. Que deux Tourbillons qui sont appuyez sur deux faces voisines, laissent quelque vuide entre eux par en bas, comme cela doit arriver tres-souvent, aussi-tost la Nature <UP></UP> qui ménage bien le terrain, vous remplit ce vuide par un petit Tourbillon ou deux, peut-estre par mille, qui n'incommodent point les autres, & ne laissent pas d'estre un ou deux, ou mille Mondes de plus. Ainsi nous pouvons voir beaucoup plus de Mondes que nostre Tourbillon n'a de faces pour en porter <UP></UP>. Je gagerois que quoy que ces petits Mondes n'ayent esté faits que pour estre jettez dans des coins de l'Univers qui fussent demeurez inutiles, quoy qu'ils soient inconnus aux autres Mondes qui les touchent, ils ne laissent pas d'estre fort contents d'eux-mesmes <UP></UP>. Ce sont ceux sans doute dont on ne découvre les petits Soleils qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, & qui sont en une quantité si prodigieuse. Enfin tous ces Tourbillons s'ajustent les uns avec les autres le mieux qu'il est possible, & comme il faut que chacun tourne autour de son Soleil sans changer de place, chacun prend la maniere de tourner, qui est la plus commode & la plus aisée dans la situation où il est. Ils s'engrainent en quelque façon les uns dans les autres comme les rouës d'une Montre, & aident mutuellement leurs mouvemens. Il est pourtant vray qu'ils agissent aussi les uns contre les autres. Chaque Monde, à ce qu'on dit, est comme un <IIM>Ballon</IIM> <UP></UP> qui s'enfle de soy-mesme, & qui s'étendroit, si on le laissoit faire, mais il est aussi-tost repoussé par les Mondes voisins, & il rentre en luy-mesme, aprés quoy il recommence à s'enfler, & ainsi de suite <UP></UP>; & on pretend que les Etoiles Fixes ne nous envoyent cette lumiere tremblante, & ne paroissent briller à reprises, que parce que leurs Tourbillons poussent perpetuellement le nostre, & en sont perpetuellement repoussez.</P097>
chunks.target_manual: <P069>There's a great deal of Sense, said I, Madam, in your proposing of this Difficulty, and no less in your not knowing how to salve it; for 'tis very judicious in it self, and unanswerable, as you understand it; and 'tis an Argument of very little Wit, to answer an Objection that is unanswerable. If our Tourbillion were in the shape of a Dy, it wou'd have six plain Superficies, and wou'd be very far from being round; yet upon every one of these six Superficies, or flat Sides, a Tourbillion might be plac'd, being of the same Figure: But instead of six flat sides, suppose it had twenty, fifty, or a thousand; then it were possible to place a thousand Tourbillions upon it, every Side bearing one; and you easily understand, that the more Superficies, or flat Sides any Body has, the nearer it approaches to <IIM>a Globe </IIM>: So a Diamond cut in Fossets on all sides, if those Fossets were very small, that Diamond wou'd be as round almost as a Pearl of the same bigness; the Tourbillions are only round in this sense, they are compos'd of an infinite number of flat Sides, and every one of 'em carries another Tourbillion: The flat Superficies are very unequal; here they are big, there they are little; the smallest Superficies of our Tourbillion, for Example, answer to the Milky Way, and support all those little Worlds; but if two Tourbillions, that rest upon two neighbouring Sides or Faces, have any void space below between 'em (as that must fall out very often) Nature, who will lose nothing, and turns all her work to the best advantage, instantly fills up that Vacuity with one, two, or it may be a thousand little Tourbillions, which does not at all trouble or incommode the rest, and yet every one of these may have a World in it; so that there may be more Worlds, than our Tourbillion has flat Sides to support: And I dare say, that although these little Worlds were only made to fill up Chinks of the Universe, which otherwise wou'd have been useless, and that they are altogether unknown to the other Worlds which touch them; yet I doubt not but they are very well contented with their own Condition, and 'tis they whose little Suns we discover by the helps of Telescopes, whose number is so prodigious. In fine, all these Tourbillions are so rightly adjusted, and join'd to one another in so delicate a Form, that every one turns round his own Sun, without changing his Situation; every one takes that way of turning, which is most proper and commode to its place: They are fixed to one another like the Wheels of a Watch, assisting one another in their Motions, and yet moving contrary to one another. And 'tis said, that every World is like a Balloon, or Foot-ball, which swells and fills of it self, and which wou'd extend farther, if it were not hinder'd by neighbouring Worlds, who press it, and then it shrinks to its first form; after that, it swells a-new, and is again depress'd. And the <UP>Philosophers </UP> pretend, that the fixed Stars transmit to us a trembling Light, and an unequal Sparkling, because their Tourbillions push against ours, and ours against theirs.</P069>

explanations: The translator adds 'Madam,' to explicitly address the Marquise, which is implied in the French source ('répondis-je' - I replied) through the ongoing dialogue format but not stated in this specific utterance. This enhances clarity and politeness for the English reader.

The translator adds 'or flat Sides,' as an explanatory gloss for 'Superficies,' which translates 'faces' (sides/faces of a die). This provides a more common or clearer term for English readers, ensuring comprehension of the geometric analogy.

The translator adds 'or flat Sides' after 'Superficies' (which translates 'faces plates' - flat faces) for consistency and to reinforce the explanation provided earlier, ensuring the reader understands these are flat surfaces.

The translator adds 'flat' before 'Superficies' (which translates 'faces'). This specifies that these surfaces are flat, maintaining consistency with earlier descriptions involving 'flat Sides' and enhancing clarity.

The translator adds 'Sides or' before 'Faces' (which translates 'faces'). This provides an alternative and perhaps more common term ('Sides') alongside 'Faces', clarifying the physical nature of these 'faces' of the tourbillions in an explanatory doublet.

The French 'la Nature qui ménage bien le terrain' (Nature who manages space well/is economical with space) is elaborated by the translator into 'Nature, who will lose nothing, and turns all her work to the best advantage,'. This expansion provides a more detailed explanation of Nature's efficiency and purposefulness for the English reader.

The translator adds 'flat' before 'Sides' (which translates 'faces') to maintain consistency with the established terminology of 'flat Sides' / 'flat Superficies' used earlier, ensuring the reader consistently understands these supporting surfaces as flat.

The French 's'ajustent les uns avec les autres le mieux qu'il est possible' (fit together as best as possible) is rendered as 'are so rightly adjusted, and join'd to one another in so delicate a Form,'. The phrase 'in so delicate a Form,' is an addition by the translator, likely to enhance the imagery and elegance of the description of the cosmic arrangement.

The French 'un Ballon' (a ball, an inflated ball) is translated as 'a Balloon, or Foot-ball,'. The addition of 'or Foot-ball,' provides a more specific and culturally familiar example of a 'ballon' for the English readership, clarifying the analogy.

The French '& il rentre en luy-mesme,' (and it returns into itself/contracts) is rendered as 'and then it shrinks to its first form;'. The phrase 'to its first form' is an addition that specifies the result of the shrinking process, providing more explicit detail than the original.

The French '& ainsi de suite;' (and so on; / and so forth;) implies the continuation of a cycle. The translator makes the next phase of the cycle explicit by adding 'and is again depress'd,' detailing what happens after the world 'swells a-new,' rather than relying on the reader's inference from 'and so on.'

The French impersonal construction 'on pretend' (it is pretended/claimed, or one pretends/claims) is rendered as 'the Philosophers pretend,'. The translator specifies the agent by adding 'the Philosophers,' likely drawing from the broader context where such scientific or natural philosophy claims were attributed to 'philosophes.'

chunks.source_manual: <P098>J'aime fort toutes ces Idées-là, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. J'aime ces Balons qui s'enflent & se desenflent à chaque moment, & ces Mondes qui se combattent toûjours, & sur tout j'aime à voir comment ce combat fait entre eux un commerce de lumiere, qui asseurément est le seul qu'ils puissent avoir.</P098>
chunks.target_manual: <P070>I am extreamly in love, said the Marquiese, with these Idea's you give me of the Balloons, which swell and fall every Moment; and those Worlds, which are always justling together: But, above all, I am pleas'd to consider, that this Strife amongst 'em produces a Commerce of Light, which is the only Traffick they can have.</P070>
source_segments: J'aime fort toutes ces Idées-là
J'aime ces Balons qui s'enflent & se desenflent à chaque moment
target_segments: with these Idea's you give me
of the Balloons, which swell and fall every Moment
explanations: The translator added 'you give me' to 'these Idea's'. In the French source, 'ces Idées-là' (those ideas) refers to concepts from the philosopher's discourse, but the act of him 'giving' these ideas is only implied by the conversational context. The addition of 'you give me' makes the philosopher's role as the provider of these ideas explicit, thereby enhancing clarity for the reader.

The translator added 'of the Balloons, which swell and fall every Moment' to function as a specifier for the preceding 'Idea's'. In the French source, the Marquise expresses her liking for 'ces Idées-là' (those ideas) and then, in a separate, parallel clause, her liking for 'ces Balons...' (these balloons...). The English translation transforms the independent statement about balloons into a prepositional phrase that directly modifies 'Idea's'. This creates an explicit link, defining the balloons as the subject matter of the ideas, a connection not made with the same syntactic directness in the original, thus clarifying the specific nature of the ideas being discussed.

chunks.source_manual: <P099>Non, non, repris-je, ce n'est pas le seul. Les Mondes voisins nous envoyent quelquefois visiter, & mesme assez magnifiquement. Il nous en vient des Cometes, qui sont toûjours ornées, ou d'une chevelure éclatante, ou d'une barbe venerable, ou d'une queüe majestueuse.</P099>
chunks.target_manual: <P071>No, no, said I, Madam; that is not the only Traffick; the neighbouring Worlds send Envoys sometimes to us, and that with a great deal of Splendor: We have Comets from thence too, who are always adorn'd with shining Hair, a venerable Beard, and a Royal Train.</P071>

explanations: The translator added 'Madam' after 'said I'. In the source, 'repris-je' (I replied) does not explicitly name the addressee in the phrase itself. Adding 'Madam' makes the address to the Marquise explicit, aligning with English conversational norms for politeness and clarity in dialogues, thus normalizing the text for the target audience.

The French 'ce n'est pas le seul' means 'it is not the only one.' The translator added 'Traffick' to specify what 'the only one' refers to, likely drawing from the preceding context of interactions or exchanges between worlds. This addition provides explicit contextual information and clarity for the English reader that is anaphoric in the source.

The source 'nous envoyent quelquefois visiter' translates to 'sometimes send [people/representatives] to visit us.' The translator specified the visitors as 'Envoys,' which elaborates on the general term. This addition makes the nature of the visit more specific, aligning with the formal tone suggested by 'assez magnifiquement' (quite magnificently) / 'with a great deal of Splendor.'

The source 'Il nous en vient des Cometes' means 'Comets come to us from there.' The translator added 'too' in the phrase 'We have Comets from thence too.' The French sentence lacks a direct lexical equivalent for 'too' in this position. This addition explicitly links the arrival of comets to the previously mentioned forms of contact (like 'Envoys'), thereby enhancing textual cohesion for the English reader.

The source describes a comet's tail as 'une queüe majestueuse' (a majestic tail). The translation uses 'a Royal Train,' where 'Train' translates 'queüe.' The adjective 'Royal' is an elaboration or specification of 'majestueuse' (majestic). While 'majestic' and 'royal' are semantically related, 'Royal' introduces a specific connotation of monarchy or kingly/queenly splendor that is not explicitly present in the more general term 'majestueuse,' possibly to create a more vivid or culturally specific image for the English audience.

chunks.source_manual: <P100>Ah! quels Deputez dit-elle en riant! On se passeroit bien de leur visite, elle ne sert qu'à faire peur. Ils ne font peur qu'aux <UP></UP> enfants, repliquay-je, à cause de leur équipage extraordinaire, mais <RW>les enfants sont en grand nombre</RW>. Les Cometes ne sont que des Planetes qui appartiennent à un Tourbillon voisin. Elles avoyent leur mouvement vers ses extremitez, mais ce Tourbillon estant peut-estre differemment pressé par ceux qui l'environnent, est plus rond par en haut, & plus plat par en bas, & c'est par en bas qu'il nous regarde. Ces Planetes <UP></UP> qui auront commencé vers le haut à se mouvoir en Cercle, ne prévoyoient pas qu'en bas le Tourbillon leur manqueroit, parce qu'il est là comme écrasé, & pour continuer leur mouvement circulaire, il faut necessairement qu'elles entrent dans un autre Tourbillon, que je suppose qui est le nostre, & qu'elles en coupent les extremitez. Aussi sont-elles toûjours fort élevées à nostre égard, elles marchent beaucoup au dessus de Saturne. Il est necessaire dans nostre Sistême, pour des raisons qui ne sont rien à nostre sujet present, que depuis Saturne jusqu'aux deux extremitez de nostre Tourbillon, il y ait un grand espace vide, & sans Planetes. Nos Ennemis nous reprochent sans cesse inutilité de ce grand espace. Qu'ils ne s'inquietent plus, nous en avons trouvé l'usage, c'est l'apartement des Planetes étrangeres qui entrent dans nostre Monde.</P100>
chunks.target_manual: <P072>Good God! said the Marquiese, laughing; What Ambassadors are these? We cou'd easily dispence with their Visits, for they do nothing but fright us. They fright <UP>only Fools </UP> and Children, Madam, said I; but of those <UP>Ignorants</UP>, I confess, there are a great number: The Comets are nothing but Planets which belong to some neighbouring Tourbillion, who make their Course toward the Extremity, or Out-side of it: But this Tourbillion being press'd by others that encompass it, 'tis rounder above than it is below, and it is from below that they appear to us. These Planets, which have begun to move in a Circle above, and not fore-seeing that their Tourbillion will sail 'em below, because it is, as it were, braz'd or squeez'd in that part; these Planets, <UP>which we call Comets, </UP> are necessitated, for the Continuance of their Circular Motion, to come into another Tourbillion, which happens sometimes to be ours, making their passage through the Extremity of it: They all appear to us highly elevated, their Course being constantly above Saturn.</P072> <P073>'Tis very necessary for the Defence of our System <NCP>(for Reasons that do not at all relate to our present Subject) </NCP> that there shou'd be a great vast space betwixt Saturn, and the Extremities of our Tourbillion, free from Planets. Our Adversaries do constantly reproach us with the unusefulness of this great Void; but let 'em not trouble their Heads with that, for we have found an Use for it; <UP>and it is the Appartment, or Chambers of State, where we receive the Stranger Planetary Ambassadors.</UP></P073>
